subQuotationList: ['Oh! pray, Miss Margaret, let us know all about it,', 'What is the gentleman s name?']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText:
I must not tell, ma am. But I know very well what it is; and I know
where he is too.
subQuotationList: ['I must not tell, ma am. But I know very well what it is; and I know\nwhere he is too.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Yes, yes, we can guess where he is; at his own house at Norland to be
sure. He is the curate of the parish I dare say.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, yes, we can guess where he is; at his own house at Norland to be\nsure. He is the curate of the parish I dare say.']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText: No, _that_ he is not. He is of no profession at all.
subQuotationList: ['No, _that_ he is not. He is of no profession at all.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Margaret, you know that all this is
an invention of your own, and that there is no such person in
existence.
subQuotationList: ['Margaret,', 'you know that all this is\nan invention of your own, and that there is no such person in\nexistence.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
Well, then, he is lately dead, Marianne, for I am sure there was such
a man once, and his name begins with an F.
subQuotationList: ['Well, then, he is lately dead, Marianne, for I am sure there was such\na man once, and his name begins with an F.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: What is the matter with Brandon?
subQuotationList: ['What is the matter with Brandon?']
speaker: John Middleton

quoteText:
I hope he has had no bad news, It must be
something extraordinary that could make Colonel Brandon leave my
breakfast table so suddenly.
subQuotationList: ['I hope he has had no bad news,', 'It must be\nsomething extraordinary that could make Colonel Brandon leave my\nbreakfast table so suddenly.']
speaker: Lady Middleton

quoteText: No bad news, Colonel, I hope;
subQuotationList: ['No bad news, Colonel, I hope;']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText: None at all, ma am, I thank you.
subQuotationList: ['None at all, ma am, I thank you.']
speaker: Colonel Brandon

quoteText:
Was it from Avignon? I hope it is not to say that your sister is
worse.
subQuotationList: ['Was it from Avignon? I hope it is not to say that your sister is\nworse.']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText: No, ma am. It came from town, and is merely a letter of business.
subQuotationList: ['No, ma am. It came from town, and is merely a letter of business.']
speaker: Colonel Brandon

quoteText:
But how came the hand to discompose you so much, if it was only a
letter of business? Come, come, this won t do, Colonel; so let us hear
the truth of it.
subQuotationList: ['But how came the hand to discompose you so much, if it was only a\nletter of business? Come, come, this won t do, Colonel; so let us hear\nthe truth of it.']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText: My dear madam, recollect what you are saying.
subQuotationList: ['My dear madam,', 'recollect what you are saying.']
speaker: Lady Middleton

quoteText: Perhaps it is to tell you that your cousin Fanny is married?
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps it is to tell you that your cousin Fanny is married?']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText: No, indeed, it is not.
subQuotationList: ['No, indeed, it is not.']
speaker: Colonel Brandon

quoteText: Well, then, I know who it is from, Colonel. And I hope she is well.
subQuotationList: ['Well, then, I know who it is from, Colonel. And I hope she is well.']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText: Whom do you mean, ma am?
subQuotationList: ['Whom do you mean, ma am?']
speaker: Colonel Brandon

quoteText: Oh! you know who I mean.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! you know who I mean.']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText:
I am particularly sorry, ma am, that I should receive this letter today, for it is on business which
requires my immediate attendance in town.
subQuotationList: ['I am particularly sorry, ma am,', 'that I should receive this letter today, for it is on business which\nrequires my immediate attendance in town.']
speaker: Colonel Brandon

quoteText:
In town! What can you have to do in town at
this time of year?
subQuotationList: ['In town!', 'What can you have to do in town at\nthis time of year?']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText:
My own loss is great, in being obliged to leave so
agreeable a party; but I am the more concerned, as I fear my presence
is necessary to gain your admittance at Whitwell.
subQuotationList: ['My own loss is great,', 'in being obliged to leave so\nagreeable a party; but I am the more concerned, as I fear my presence\nis necessary to gain your admittance at Whitwell.']
speaker: Colonel Brandon

quoteText: But if you write a note to the housekeeper, Mr. Brandon, will it not be sufficient?
subQuotationList: ['But if you write a note to the housekeeper, Mr. Brandon,', 'will it not be sufficient?']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
We must go, It shall not be put off when we are so
near it. You cannot go to town till tomorrow, Brandon, that is all.
subQuotationList: ['We must go,', 'It shall not be put off when we are so\nnear it. You cannot go to town till tomorrow, Brandon, that is all.']
speaker: John Middleton
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Colonel Brandon', 'John Middleton']], [['Colonel Brandon', 'John Middleton'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon']]]

quoteText:
I wish it could be so easily settled. But it is not in my power to
delay my journey for one day!
subQuotationList: ['I wish it could be so easily settled. But it is not in my power to\ndelay my journey for one day!']
speaker: Colonel Brandon

quoteText: If you would but let us know what your business is, we might see whether it could be put off or not.
subQuotationList: ['If you would but let us know what your business is,', 'we might see whether it could be put off or not.']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Colonel Brandon'], ['Elinor', 'Marianne', 'John Middleton', 'Mrs. Jennings', 'Lady Middleton']], [['Elinor', 'Marianne', 'John Middleton', 'Mrs. Jennings', 'Lady Middleton']]]

quoteText:
You would not be six hours later, if you were to
defer your journey till our return.
subQuotationList: ['You would not be six hours later,', 'if you were to\ndefer your journey till our return.']
speaker: Mr. Willoughby

quoteText: I cannot afford to lose _one_ hour.
subQuotationList: ['I cannot afford to lose _one_ hour.']
speaker: Colonel Brandon

quoteText:
There
are some people who cannot bear a party of pleasure. Brandon is one of
them. He was afraid of catching cold I dare say, and invented this
trick for getting out of it. I would lay fifty guineas the letter was
of his own writing.
subQuotationList:
['There
are some people who cannot bear a party of pleasure. Brandon is one of
them. He was afraid of catching cold I dare say, and invented this
trick for getting out of it. I would lay fifty guineas the letter was
of his own writing.']
speaker: Mr. Willoughby
referringExpression: Willoughby say in a low voice to Marianne

quoteText: I have no doubt of it,
subQuotationList: ['I have no doubt of it,']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
There is no persuading you to change your mind, Brandon, I know of
old, when once you are determined on anything. But,
however, I hope you will think better of it. Consider, here are the two
Miss Careys come over from Newton, the three Miss Dashwoods walked up
from the cottage, and Mr. Willoughby got up two hours before his usual
time, on purpose to go to Whitwell.
subQuotationList:
['There is no persuading you to change your mind, Brandon, I know of
old,', 'when once you are determined on anything. But,
however, I hope you will think better of it. Consider, here are the two
Miss Careys come over from Newton, the three Miss Dashwoods walked up
from the cottage, and Mr. Willoughby got up two hours before his usual
time, on purpose to go to Whitwell.']
speaker: John Middleton
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon']], [['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Lady Middleton', 'Mrs. Jennings'], ['Margaret', 'Marianne', 'Elinor'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby']]]

quoteText: Well, then, when will you come back again?
subQuotationList: ['Well, then, when will you come back again?']
speaker: John Middleton

quoteText:
I hope we shall see you at Barton, as soon as
you can conveniently leave town; and we must put off the party to
Whitwell till you return.
subQuotationList: ['I hope we shall see you at Barton,', 'as soon as\nyou can conveniently leave town; and we must put off the party to\nWhitwell till you return.']
speaker: Lady Middleton
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elinor', 'Marianne', 'John Middleton', 'Mrs. Jennings', 'Lady Middleton'], ['Colonel Brandon']], [['Colonel Brandon'], ['Elinor', 'Marianne', 'John Middleton', 'Mrs. Jennings', 'Lady Middleton'], ['Colonel Brandon']]]

quoteText:
You are very obliging. But it is so uncertain, when I may have it in
my power to return, that I dare not engage for it at all.
subQuotationList: ['You are very obliging. But it is so uncertain, when I may have it in\nmy power to return, that I dare not engage for it at all.']
speaker: Colonel Brandon

quoteText:
Oh! he must and shall come back, If he is not here
by the end of the week, I shall go after him.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! he must and shall come back,', 'If he is not here\nby the end of the week, I shall go after him.']
speaker: John Middleton

quoteText:
Ay, so do, Sir John, and then perhaps you may
find out what his business is.
subQuotationList: ['Ay, so do, Sir John,', 'and then perhaps you may\nfind out what his business is.']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText:
I do not want to pry into other men s concerns. I suppose it is
something he is ashamed of.
subQuotationList: ['I do not want to pry into other men s concerns. I suppose it is\nsomething he is ashamed of.']
speaker: John Middleton

quoteText: You do not go to town on horseback, do you?
subQuotationList: ['You do not go to town on horseback, do you?']
speaker: John Middleton

quoteText: No. Only to Honiton. I shall then go post.
subQuotationList: ['No. Only to Honiton. I shall then go post.']
speaker: Colonel Brandon

quoteText:
Well, as you are resolved to go, I wish you a good journey. But you
had better change your mind.
subQuotationList: ['Well, as you are resolved to go, I wish you a good journey. But you\nhad better change your mind.']
speaker: John Middleton

quoteText: I assure you it is not in my power.
subQuotationList: ['I assure you it is not in my power.']
speaker: Colonel Brandon

quoteText:
Is there no chance of my seeing you and your sisters in town this
winter, Miss Dashwood?
subQuotationList: ['Is there no chance of my seeing you and your sisters in town this\nwinter, Miss Dashwood?']
speaker: Colonel Brandon

quoteText: I am afraid, none at all.
subQuotationList: ['I am afraid, none at all.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Then I must bid you farewell for a longer time than I should wish to
do.
subQuotationList: ['Then I must bid you farewell for a longer time than I should wish to\ndo.']
speaker: Colonel Brandon

quoteText:
Come Colonel, before you go, do let us know what
you are going about.
subQuotationList: ['Come Colonel,', 'before you go, do let us know what\nyou are going about.']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Colonel Brandon']], [['Colonel Brandon'], ['Elinor', 'Marianne', 'John Middleton', 'Mrs. Jennings', 'Lady Middleton'], ['Colonel Brandon']]]

quoteText: I can guess what his business is, however,
subQuotationList: ['I can guess what his business is, however,']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText: Yes; it is about Miss Williams, I am sure.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; it is about Miss Williams, I am sure.']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText: And who is Miss Williams?
subQuotationList: ['And who is Miss Williams?']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
What! do not you know who Miss Williams is? I am sure you must have
heard of her before. She is a relation of the Colonel s, my dear; a
very near relation. We will not say how near, for fear of shocking the
young ladies.
subQuotationList:
['What! do not you know who Miss Williams is? I am sure you must have
heard of her before. She is a relation of the Colonel s, my dear; a
very near relation. We will not say how near, for fear of shocking the
young ladies.']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText: She is his natural daughter.
subQuotationList: ['She is his natural daughter.']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText: Indeed!
subQuotationList: ['Indeed!']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Oh, yes; and as like him as she can stare. I dare say the Colonel will
leave her all his fortune.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, yes; and as like him as she can stare. I dare say the Colonel will\nleave her all his fortune.']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText:
I have found you out in
spite of all your tricks. I know where you spent the morning.
subQuotationList: ['I have found you out in\nspite of all your tricks. I know where you spent the morning.']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings
referringExpression: she leant behind her and Willoughby and said to Marianne

quoteText: Where, pray?
subQuotationList: ['Where, pray?']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
Did not you know, that we had been out in my
curricle?
subQuotationList: ['Did not you know,', 'that we had been out in my\ncurricle?']
speaker: Mr. Willoughby

quoteText:
Yes, yes, Mr. Impudence, I know that very well, and I was determined
to find out _where_ you had been to. I hope you like your house, Miss
Marianne. It is a very large one, I know; and when I come to see you, I
hope you will have new-furnished it, for it wanted it very much when I
was there six years ago.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, yes, Mr. Impudence, I know that very well, and I was determined
to find out _where_ you had been to. I hope you like your house, Miss
Marianne. It is a very large one, I know; and when I come to see you, I
hope you will have new-furnished it, for it wanted it very much when I
was there six years ago.']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText:
Why should you imagine, Elinor, that we did not go there, or that we
did not see the house? Is not it what you have often wished to do
yourself?
subQuotationList: ['Why should you imagine, Elinor, that we did not go there, or that we\ndid not see the house? Is not it what you have often wished to do\nyourself?']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
Yes, Marianne, but I would not go while Mrs. Smith was there, and with
no other companion than Mr. Willoughby.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, Marianne, but I would not go while Mrs. Smith was there, and with\nno other companion than Mr. Willoughby.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Mr. Willoughby however is the only person who can have a right to show
that house; and as he went in an open carriage, it was impossible to
have any other companion. I never spent a pleasanter morning in my
life.
subQuotationList:
['Mr. Willoughby however is the only person who can have a right to show
that house; and as he went in an open carriage, it was impossible to
have any other companion. I never spent a pleasanter morning in my
life.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
I am afraid, that the pleasantness of an employment
does not always evince its propriety.
subQuotationList: ['I am afraid,', 'that the pleasantness of an employment\ndoes not always evince its propriety.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
On the contrary, nothing can be a stronger proof of it, Elinor; for if
there had been any real impropriety in what I did, I should have been
sensible of it at the time, for we always know when we are acting
wrong, and with such a conviction I could have had no pleasure.
subQuotationList:
['On the contrary, nothing can be a stronger proof of it, Elinor; for if
there had been any real impropriety in what I did, I should have been
sensible of it at the time, for we always know when we are acting
wrong, and with such a conviction I could have had no pleasure.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
But, my dear Marianne, as it has already exposed you to some very
impertinent remarks, do you not now begin to doubt the discretion of
your own conduct?
subQuotationList: ['But, my dear Marianne, as it has already exposed you to some very\nimpertinent remarks, do you not now begin to doubt the discretion of\nyour own conduct?']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
If the impertinent remarks of Mrs. Jennings are to be the proof of
impropriety in conduct, we are all offending every moment of our lives.
I value not her censure any more than I should do her commendation. I
am not sensible of having done anything wrong in walking over Mrs.
Smith s grounds, or in seeing her house. They will one day be Mr.
Willoughby s, and
subQuotationList:
['If the impertinent remarks of Mrs. Jennings are to be the proof of
impropriety in conduct, we are all offending every moment of our lives.
I value not her censure any more than I should do her commendation. I
am not sensible of having done anything wrong in walking over Mrs.
Smith s grounds, or in seeing her house. They will one day be Mr.
Willoughby s, and']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
If they were one day to be your own, Marianne, you would not be
justified in what you have done.
subQuotationList: ['If they were one day to be your own, Marianne, you would not be\njustified in what you have done.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Perhaps, Elinor, it
_was_ rather ill-judged in me to go to Allenham; but Mr. Willoughby
wanted particularly to show me the place; and it is a charming house, I
assure you. There is one remarkably pretty sitting room up stairs; of a
nice comfortable size for constant use, and with modern furniture it
would be delightful. It is a corner room, and has windows on two sides.
On one side you look across the bowling-green, behind the house, to a
beautiful hanging wood, and on the other you have a view of the church
and village, and, beyond them, of those fine bold hills that we have so
often admired. I did not see it to advantage, for nothing could be more
forlorn than the furniture, but if it were newly fitted up a couple of
hundred pounds, Willoughby says, would make it one of the pleasantest
summer-rooms in England.
subQuotationList:
['Perhaps, Elinor, it
_was_ rather ill-judged in me to go to Allenham; but Mr. Willoughby
wanted particularly to show me the place; and it is a charming house, I
assure you. There is one remarkably pretty sitting room up stairs; of a
nice comfortable size for constant use, and with modern furniture it
would be delightful. It is a corner room, and has windows on two sides.
On one side you look across the bowling-green, behind the house, to a
beautiful hanging wood, and on the other you have a view of the church
and village, and, beyond them, of those fine bold hills that we have so
often admired. I did not see it to advantage, for nothing could be more
forlorn than the furniture, but if it were newly fitted up a couple of
hundred pounds, Willoughby says, would make it one of the pleasantest
summer-rooms in England.']
speaker: Marianne
referringExpression: she came to her sister again and said

quoteText:
Something very melancholy must be the matter, I am sure, I
could see it in his face. Poor man! I am afraid his circumstances may
be bad. The estate at Delaford was never reckoned more than two
thousand a year, and his brother left everything sadly involved. I do
think he must have been sent for about money matters, for what else can
it be? I wonder whether it is so. I would give anything to know the
truth of it. Perhaps it is about Miss Williams and, by the bye, I dare
say it is, because he looked so conscious when I mentioned her. May be
she is ill in town; nothing in the world more likely, for I have a
notion she is always rather sickly. I would lay any wager it is about
Miss Williams. It is not so very likely he should be distressed in his
circumstances _now_, for he is a very prudent man, and to be sure must
have cleared the estate by this time. I wonder what it can be! May be
his sister is worse at Avignon, and has sent for him over. His setting
off in such a hurry seems very like it. Well, I wish him out of all his
trouble with all my heart, and a good wife into the bargain.
subQuotationList:
['Something very melancholy must be the matter, I am sure,', 'I
could see it in his face. Poor man! I am afraid his circumstances may
be bad. The estate at Delaford was never reckoned more than two
thousand a year, and his brother left everything sadly involved. I do
think he must have been sent for about money matters, for what else can
it be? I wonder whether it is so. I would give anything to know the
truth of it. Perhaps it is about Miss Williams and, by the bye, I dare
say it is, because he looked so conscious when I mentioned her. May be
she is ill in town; nothing in the world more likely, for I have a
notion she is always rather sickly. I would lay any wager it is about
Miss Williams. It is not so very likely he should be distressed in his
circumstances _now_, for he is a very prudent man, and to be sure must
have cleared the estate by this time. I wonder what it can be! May be
his sister is worse at Avignon, and has sent for him over. His setting
off in such a hurry seems very like it. Well, I wish him out of all his
trouble with all my heart, and a good wife into the bargain.']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon']]]

quoteText:
What! Improve this dear cottage! No. _That_ I will
never consent to. Not a stone must be added to its walls, not an inch
to its size, if my feelings are regarded.
subQuotationList: ['What!', 'Improve this dear cottage! No. _That_ I will\nnever consent to. Not a stone must be added to its walls, not an inch\nto its size, if my feelings are regarded.']
speaker: Mr. Willoughby

quoteText:
Do not be alarmed, nothing of the kind will be
done; for my mother will never have money enough to attempt it.
subQuotationList: ['Do not be alarmed,', 'nothing of the kind will be\ndone; for my mother will never have money enough to attempt it.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
I am heartily glad of it, May she always be poor, if she
can employ her riches no better.
subQuotationList: ['I am heartily glad of it,', 'May she always be poor, if she\ncan employ her riches no better.']
speaker: Mr. Willoughby

quoteText:
Thank you, Willoughby. But you may be assured that I would not
sacrifice one sentiment of local attachment of yours, or of any one
whom I loved, for all the improvements in the world. Depend upon it
that whatever unemployed sum may remain, when I make up my accounts in
the spring, I would even rather lay it uselessly by than dispose of it
in a manner so painful to you. But are you really so attached to this
place as to see no defect in it?
subQuotationList:
['Thank you, Willoughby. But you may be assured that I would not
sacrifice one sentiment of local attachment of yours, or of any one
whom I loved, for all the improvements in the world. Depend upon it
that whatever unemployed sum may remain, when I make up my accounts in
the spring, I would even rather lay it uselessly by than dispose of it
in a manner so painful to you. But are you really so attached to this
place as to see no defect in it?']
speaker: Elinor
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby']]]

quoteText:
I am, To me it is faultless. Nay, more, I consider it as
the only form of building in which happiness is attainable, and were I
rich enough I would instantly pull Combe down, and build it up again in
the exact plan of this cottage.
subQuotationList:
['I am,', 'To me it is faultless. Nay, more, I consider it as
the only form of building in which happiness is attainable, and were I
rich enough I would instantly pull Combe down, and build it up again in
the exact plan of this cottage.']
speaker: Mr. Willoughby

quoteText: With dark narrow stairs and a kitchen that smokes, I suppose,
subQuotationList: ['With dark narrow stairs and a kitchen that smokes, I suppose,']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Yes, with all and every thing
belonging to it; in no one convenience or inconvenience about it,
should the least variation be perceptible. Then, and then only, under
such a roof, I might perhaps be as happy at Combe as I have been at
Barton.
subQuotationList:
['Yes,', 'with all and every thing
belonging to it; in no one convenience or inconvenience about it,
should the least variation be perceptible. Then, and then only, under
such a roof, I might perhaps be as happy at Combe as I have been at
Barton.']
speaker: Mr. Willoughby

quoteText:
I flatter myself, that even under the disadvantage
of better rooms and a broader staircase, you will hereafter find your
own house as faultless as you now do this.
subQuotationList: ['I flatter myself,', 'that even under the disadvantage\nof better rooms and a broader staircase, you will hereafter find your\nown house as faultless as you now do this.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
There certainly are circumstances, which might
greatly endear it to me; but this place will always have one claim of
my affection, which no other can possibly share.
subQuotationList: ['There certainly are circumstances,', 'which might\ngreatly endear it to me; but this place will always have one claim of\nmy affection, which no other can possibly share.']
speaker: Mr. Willoughby

quoteText:
How often did I wish, when I was at Allenham this time
twelvemonth, that Barton cottage were inhabited! I never passed within
view of it without admiring its situation, and grieving that no one
should live in it. How little did I then think that the very first news
I should hear from Mrs. Smith, when I next came into the country, would
be that Barton cottage was taken: and I felt an immediate satisfaction
and interest in the event, which nothing but a kind of prescience of
what happiness I should experience from it, can account for. Must it
not have been so, Marianne?
subQuotationList:
['How often did I wish,', 'when I was at Allenham this time
twelvemonth, that Barton cottage were inhabited! I never passed within
view of it without admiring its situation, and grieving that no one
should live in it. How little did I then think that the very first news
I should hear from Mrs. Smith, when I next came into the country, would
be that Barton cottage was taken: and I felt an immediate satisfaction
and interest in the event, which nothing but a kind of prescience of
what happiness I should experience from it, can account for. Must it
not have been so, Marianne?']
speaker: Mr. Willoughby

quoteText:
And yet this house you would
spoil, Mrs. Dashwood? You would rob it of its simplicity by imaginary
improvement! and this dear parlour in which our acquaintance first
began, and in which so many happy hours have been since spent by us
together, you would degrade to the condition of a common entrance, and
every body would be eager to pass through the room which has hitherto
contained within itself more real accommodation and comfort than any
other apartment of the handsomest dimensions in the world could
possibly afford.
subQuotationList:
['And yet this house you would
spoil, Mrs. Dashwood? You would rob it of its simplicity by imaginary
improvement! and this dear parlour in which our acquaintance first
began, and in which so many happy hours have been since spent by us
together, you would degrade to the condition of a common entrance, and
every body would be eager to pass through the room which has hitherto
contained within itself more real accommodation and comfort than any
other apartment of the handsomest dimensions in the world could
possibly afford.']
speaker: Mr. Willoughby

quoteText:
You are a good woman, Your promise makes me easy.
Extend it a little farther, and it will make me happy. Tell me that not
only your house will remain the same, but that I shall ever find you
and yours as unchanged as your dwelling; and that you will always
consider me with the kindness which has made everything belonging to
you so dear to me.
subQuotationList:
['You are a good woman,', 'Your promise makes me easy.
Extend it a little farther, and it will make me happy. Tell me that not
only your house will remain the same, but that I shall ever find you
and yours as unchanged as your dwelling; and that you will always
consider me with the kindness which has made everything belonging to
you so dear to me.']
speaker: Mr. Willoughby

quoteText:
Shall we see you tomorrow to dinner? I do not ask you to come in the morning, for we must
walk to the park, to call on Lady Middleton.
subQuotationList: ['Shall we see you tomorrow to dinner?', 'I do not ask you to come in the morning, for we must\nwalk to the park, to call on Lady Middleton.']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood

quoteText: Is anything the matter with her? is she ill?
subQuotationList: ['Is anything the matter with her?', 'is she ill?']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood

quoteText:
I hope not, It is I who may rather expect to be ill for I
am now suffering under a very heavy disappointment!
subQuotationList: ['I hope not,', 'It is I who may rather expect to be ill for I\nam now suffering under a very heavy disappointment!']
speaker: Mr. Willoughby

quoteText: Disappointment?
subQuotationList: ['Disappointment?']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood

quoteText:
Yes, for I am unable to keep my engagement with you. Mrs. Smith has
this morning exercised the privilege of riches upon a poor dependent
cousin, by sending me on business to London. I have just received my
dispatches, and taken my farewell of Allenham; and by way of
exhilaration I am now come to take my farewell of you.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, for I am unable to keep my engagement with you. Mrs. Smith has
this morning exercised the privilege of riches upon a poor dependent
cousin, by sending me on business to London. I have just received my
dispatches, and taken my farewell of Allenham; and by way of
exhilaration I am now come to take my farewell of you.']
speaker: Mr. Willoughby

quoteText: To London! and are you going this morning?
subQuotationList: ['To London! and are you going this morning?']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood

quoteText: Almost this moment.
subQuotationList: ['Almost this moment.']
speaker: Mr. Willoughby

quoteText:
This is very unfortunate. But Mrs. Smith must be obliged; and her
business will not detain you from us long I hope.
subQuotationList: ['This is very unfortunate. But Mrs. Smith must be obliged; and her\nbusiness will not detain you from us long I hope.']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood

quoteText:
You are very kind, but I have no idea of
returning into Devonshire immediately. My visits to Mrs. Smith are
never repeated within the twelvemonth.
subQuotationList: ['You are very kind, but I have no idea of\nreturning into Devonshire immediately. My visits to Mrs. Smith are\nnever repeated within the twelvemonth.']
speaker: Mr. Willoughby

quoteText:
And is Mrs. Smith your only friend? Is Allenham the only house in the
neighbourhood to which you will be welcome? For shame, Willoughby, can
you wait for an invitation here?
subQuotationList: ['And is Mrs. Smith your only friend? Is Allenham the only house in the\nneighbourhood to which you will be welcome? For shame, Willoughby, can\nyou wait for an invitation here?']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood

quoteText: You are too good.
subQuotationList: ['You are too good.']
speaker: Mr. Willoughby

quoteText:
I have only to add, my dear Willoughby, that at Barton cottage you
will always be welcome; for I will not press you to return here
immediately, because you only can judge how far _that_ might be
pleasing to Mrs. Smith; and on this head I shall be no more disposed to
question your judgment than to doubt your inclination.
subQuotationList:
['I have only to add, my dear Willoughby, that at Barton cottage you
will always be welcome; for I will not press you to return here
immediately, because you only can judge how far _that_ might be
pleasing to Mrs. Smith; and on this head I shall be no more disposed to
question your judgment than to doubt your inclination.']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby']]]

quoteText:
My engagements at present, are of
such a nature that I dare not flatter myself
subQuotationList: ['My engagements at present,', 'are of\nsuch a nature that I dare not flatter myself']
speaker: Mr. Willoughby

quoteText:
It is folly to linger in this manner. I will not torment myself
any longer by remaining among friends whose society it is impossible
for me now to enjoy.
subQuotationList: ['It is folly to linger in this manner. I will not torment myself\nany longer by remaining among friends whose society it is impossible\nfor me now to enjoy.']
speaker: Mr. Willoughby
mentionTextsList: [['friends whose society it is impossible\nfor me now to enjoy']]

quoteText: Our dear Willoughby is now some miles from Barton, Elinor, and with how heavy a heart does he travel?
subQuotationList: ['Our dear Willoughby is now some miles from Barton, Elinor,', 'and with how heavy a heart does he travel?']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood

quoteText:
It is all very strange. So suddenly to be gone! It seems but the work
of a moment. And last night he was with us so happy, so cheerful, so
affectionate? And now, after only ten minutes notice Gone too without
intending to return! Something more than what he owned to us must have
happened. He did not speak, he did not behave like himself. _You_ must
have seen the difference as well as I. What can it be? Can they have
quarrelled? Why else should he have shown such unwillingness to accept
your invitation here?
subQuotationList:
['It is all very strange. So suddenly to be gone! It seems but the work
of a moment. And last night he was with us so happy, so cheerful, so
affectionate? And now, after only ten minutes notice Gone too without
intending to return! Something more than what he owned to us must have
happened. He did not speak, he did not behave like himself. _You_ must
have seen the difference as well as I. What can it be? Can they have
quarrelled? Why else should he have shown such unwillingness to accept
your invitation here?']
speaker: Elinor
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mrs. Dashwood', 'Marianne', 'Elinor'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Elinor', 'Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Marianne', 'Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mrs. Dashwood']]]

quoteText:
It was not inclination that he wanted, Elinor; I could plainly see
_that_. He had not the power of accepting it. I have thought it all
over I assure you, and I can perfectly account for every thing that at
first seemed strange to me as well as to you.
subQuotationList:
['It was not inclination that he wanted, Elinor; I could plainly see
_that_. He had not the power of accepting it. I have thought it all
over I assure you, and I can perfectly account for every thing that at
first seemed strange to me as well as to you.']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood

quoteText: Can you, indeed!
subQuotationList: ['Can you, indeed!']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Yes. I have explained it to myself in the most satisfactory way; but
you, Elinor, who love to doubt where you can it will not satisfy _you_,
I know; but you shall not talk _me_ out of my trust in it. I am
persuaded that Mrs. Smith suspects his regard for Marianne, disapproves
of it, (perhaps because she has other views for him,) and on that
account is eager to get him away; and that the business which she sends
him off to transact is invented as an excuse to dismiss him. This is
what I believe to have happened. He is, moreover, aware that she _does_
disapprove the connection, he dares not therefore at present confess to
her his engagement with Marianne, and he feels himself obliged, from
his dependent situation, to give into her schemes, and absent himself
from Devonshire for a while. You will tell me, I know, that this may or
may _not_ have happened; but I will listen to no cavil, unless you can
point out any other method of understanding the affair as satisfactory
at this. And now, Elinor, what have you to say?
subQuotationList:
['Yes. I have explained it to myself in the most satisfactory way; but
you, Elinor, who love to doubt where you can it will not satisfy _you_,
I know; but you shall not talk _me_ out of my trust in it. I am
persuaded that Mrs. Smith suspects his regard for Marianne, disapproves
of it, (perhaps because she has other views for him,) and on that
account is eager to get him away; and that the business which she sends
him off to transact is invented as an excuse to dismiss him. This is
what I believe to have happened. He is, moreover, aware that she _does_
disapprove the connection, he dares not therefore at present confess to
her his engagement with Marianne, and he feels himself obliged, from
his dependent situation, to give into her schemes, and absent himself
from Devonshire for a while. You will tell me, I know, that this may or
may _not_ have happened; but I will listen to no cavil, unless you can
point out any other method of understanding the affair as satisfactory
at this. And now, Elinor, what have you to say?']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elinor'], ['Elinor'], ['Elinor'], ['Elinor'], ['Elinor'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Marianne'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Marianne'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Elinor'], ['Elinor'], ['Elinor'], ['Elinor']]]

quoteText: Nothing, for you have anticipated my answer.
subQuotationList: ['Nothing, for you have anticipated my answer.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Then you would have told me, that it might or might not have happened.
Oh, Elinor, how incomprehensible are your feelings! You had rather take
evil upon credit than good. You had rather look out for misery for
Marianne, and guilt for poor Willoughby, than an apology for the
latter. You are resolved to think him blameable, because he took leave
of us with less affection than his usual behaviour has shown. And is no
allowance to be made for inadvertence, or for spirits depressed by
recent disappointment? Are no probabilities to be accepted, merely
because they are not certainties? Is nothing due to the man whom we
have all such reason to love, and no reason in the world to think ill
of? To the possibility of motives unanswerable in themselves, though
unavoidably secret for a while? And, after all, what is it you suspect
him of?
subQuotationList:
['Then you would have told me, that it might or might not have happened.
Oh, Elinor, how incomprehensible are your feelings! You had rather take
evil upon credit than good. You had rather look out for misery for
Marianne, and guilt for poor Willoughby, than an apology for the
latter. You are resolved to think him blameable, because he took leave
of us with less affection than his usual behaviour has shown. And is no
allowance to be made for inadvertence, or for spirits depressed by
recent disappointment? Are no probabilities to be accepted, merely
because they are not certainties? Is nothing due to the man whom we
have all such reason to love, and no reason in the world to think ill
of? To the possibility of motives unanswerable in themselves, though
unavoidably secret for a while? And, after all, what is it you suspect
him of?']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood
mentionTextsList: [['you', 'Elinor', 'your', 'You', 'You', 'Marianne', 'poor Willoughby', 'You', 'him', 'he', 'us', 'his', 'the man whom we\nhave all such reason to love', 'you', 'him']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elinor'], ['Elinor'], ['Elinor'], ['Elinor'], ['Elinor'], ['Marianne'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Elinor'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Elinor', 'Mrs. Dashwood', 'Margaret'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Elinor'], ['Mr. Willoughby']]]

quoteText:
I can hardly tell myself. But suspicion of something unpleasant is the
inevitable consequence of such an alteration as we just witnessed in
him. There is great truth, however, in what you have now urged of the
allowances which ought to be made for him, and it is my wish to be
candid in my judgment of every body. Willoughby may undoubtedly have
very sufficient reasons for his conduct, and I will hope that he has.
But it would have been more like Willoughby to acknowledge them at
once. Secrecy may be advisable; but still I cannot help wondering at
its being practiced by him.
subQuotationList:
['I can hardly tell myself. But suspicion of something unpleasant is the
inevitable consequence of such an alteration as we just witnessed in
him. There is great truth, however, in what you have now urged of the
allowances which ought to be made for him, and it is my wish to be
candid in my judgment of every body. Willoughby may undoubtedly have
very sufficient reasons for his conduct, and I will hope that he has.
But it would have been more like Willoughby to acknowledge them at
once. Secrecy may be advisable; but still I cannot help wondering at
its being practiced by him.']
speaker: Elinor
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elinor', 'Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby']]]

quoteText:
Do not blame him, however, for departing from his character, where the
deviation is necessary. But you really do admit the justice of what I
have said in his defence? I am happy and he is acquitted.
subQuotationList: ['Do not blame him, however, for departing from his character, where the\ndeviation is necessary. But you really do admit the justice of what I\nhave said in his defence? I am happy and he is acquitted.']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood

quoteText:
Not entirely. It may be proper to conceal their engagement (if they
_are_ engaged) from Mrs. Smith and if that is the case, it must be
highly expedient for Willoughby to be but little in Devonshire at
present. But this is no excuse for their concealing it from us.
subQuotationList:
['Not entirely. It may be proper to conceal their engagement (if they
_are_ engaged) from Mrs. Smith and if that is the case, it must be
highly expedient for Willoughby to be but little in Devonshire at
present. But this is no excuse for their concealing it from us.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Concealing it from us! my dear child, do you accuse Willoughby and
Marianne of concealment? This is strange indeed, when your eyes have
been reproaching them every day for incautiousness.
subQuotationList: ['Concealing it from us! my dear child, do you accuse Willoughby and\nMarianne of concealment? This is strange indeed, when your eyes have\nbeen reproaching them every day for incautiousness.']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood

quoteText:
I want no proof of their affection, but of their
engagement I do.
subQuotationList: ['I want no proof of their affection,', 'but of their\nengagement I do.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText: I am perfectly satisfied of both.
subQuotationList: ['I am perfectly satisfied of both.']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood

quoteText:
Yet not a syllable has been said to you on the subject, by either of
them.
subQuotationList: ['Yet not a syllable has been said to you on the subject, by either of\nthem.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
I have not wanted syllables where actions have spoken so plainly. Has
not his behaviour to Marianne and to all of us, for at least the last
fortnight, declared that he loved and considered her as his future
wife, and that he felt for us the attachment of the nearest relation?
Have we not perfectly understood each other? Has not my consent been
daily asked by his looks, his manner, his attentive and affectionate
respect? My Elinor, is it possible to doubt their engagement? How could
such a thought occur to you? How is it to be supposed that Willoughby,
persuaded as he must be of your sister s love, should leave her, and
leave her perhaps for months, without telling her of his
affection; that they should part without a mutual exchange of
confidence?
subQuotationList:
['I have not wanted syllables where actions have spoken so plainly. Has
not his behaviour to Marianne and to all of us, for at least the last
fortnight, declared that he loved and considered her as his future
wife, and that he felt for us the attachment of the nearest relation?
Have we not perfectly understood each other? Has not my consent been
daily asked by his looks, his manner, his attentive and affectionate
respect? My Elinor, is it possible to doubt their engagement? How could
such a thought occur to you? How is it to be supposed that Willoughby,
persuaded as he must be of your sister s love, should leave her, and
leave her perhaps for months, without telling her of his
affection; that they should part without a mutual exchange of
confidence?']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Marianne'], ['Elinor', 'Mrs. Dashwood', 'Margaret'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Marianne'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Elinor', 'Mrs. Dashwood', 'Margaret'], ['Mr. Willoughby', 'Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Elinor'], ['Marianne', 'Mr. Willoughby'], ['Elinor'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Marianne'], ['Marianne'], ['Marianne'], ['Marianne'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Marianne', 'Mr. Willoughby']]]

quoteText:
I confess, that every circumstance except _one_ is
in favour of their engagement; but that _one_ is the total silence of
both on the subject, and with me it almost outweighs every other.
subQuotationList: ['I confess,', 'that every circumstance except _one_ is\nin favour of their engagement; but that _one_ is the total silence of\nboth on the subject, and with me it almost outweighs every other.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
How strange this is! You must think wretchedly indeed of Willoughby,
if, after all that has openly passed between them, you can doubt the
nature of the terms on which they are together. Has he been acting a
part in his behaviour to your sister all this time? Do you suppose him
really indifferent to her?
subQuotationList:
['How strange this is! You must think wretchedly indeed of Willoughby,
if, after all that has openly passed between them, you can doubt the
nature of the terms on which they are together. Has he been acting a
part in his behaviour to your sister all this time? Do you suppose him
really indifferent to her?']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elinor'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Marianne', 'Mr. Willoughby'], ['Elinor'], ['Marianne', 'Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Elinor'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Marianne']]]

quoteText: No, I cannot think that. He must and does love her I am sure.
subQuotationList: ['No, I cannot think that. He must and does love her I am sure.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
But with a strange kind of tenderness, if he can leave her with such
indifference, such carelessness of the future, as you attribute to
him.
subQuotationList: ['But with a strange kind of tenderness, if he can leave her with such\nindifference, such carelessness of the future, as you attribute to\nhim.']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood

quoteText:
You must remember, my dear mother, that I have never considered this
matter as certain. I have had my doubts, I confess; but they are
fainter than they were, and they may soon be entirely done away. If we
find they correspond, every fear of mine will be removed.
subQuotationList:
['You must remember, my dear mother, that I have never considered this
matter as certain. I have had my doubts, I confess; but they are
fainter than they were, and they may soon be entirely done away. If we
find they correspond, every fear of mine will be removed.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
A mighty concession indeed! If you were to see them at the altar, you
would suppose they were going to be married. Ungracious girl! But _I_
require no such proof. Nothing in my opinion has ever passed to justify
doubt; no secrecy has been attempted; all has been uniformly open and
unreserved. You cannot doubt your sister s wishes. It must be
Willoughby therefore whom you suspect. But why? Is he not a man of
honour and feeling? Has there been any inconsistency on his side to
create alarm? can he be deceitful?
subQuotationList:
['A mighty concession indeed! If you were to see them at the altar, you
would suppose they were going to be married. Ungracious girl! But _I_
require no such proof. Nothing in my opinion has ever passed to justify
doubt; no secrecy has been attempted; all has been uniformly open and
unreserved. You cannot doubt your sister s wishes. It must be
Willoughby therefore whom you suspect. But why? Is he not a man of
honour and feeling? Has there been any inconsistency on his side to
create alarm? can he be deceitful?']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elinor'], ['Marianne', 'Mr. Willoughby'], ['Elinor'], ['Marianne', 'Mr. Willoughby'], ['Elinor'], ['Elinor'], ['Marianne'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Elinor'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby']]]

quoteText:
I hope not, I believe not, I love Willoughby,
sincerely love him; and suspicion of his integrity cannot be more
painful to yourself than to me. It has been involuntary, and I will not
encourage it. I was startled, I confess, by the alteration in his
manners this morning; he did not speak like himself, and did not return
your kindness with any cordiality. But all this may be explained by
such a situation of his affairs as you have supposed. He had just
parted from my sister, had seen her leave him in the greatest
affliction; and if he felt obliged, from a fear of offending Mrs.
Smith, to resist the temptation of returning here soon, and yet aware
that by declining your invitation, by saying that he was going away for
some time, he should seem to act an ungenerous, a suspicious part by
our family, he might well be embarrassed and disturbed. In such a case,
a plain and open avowal of his difficulties would have been more to his
honour I think, as well as more consistent with his general
character; but I will not raise objections against any one s conduct on
so illiberal a foundation, as a difference in judgment from myself, or
a deviation from what I may think right and consistent.
subQuotationList:
['I hope not, I believe not,', 'I love Willoughby,
sincerely love him; and suspicion of his integrity cannot be more
painful to yourself than to me. It has been involuntary, and I will not
encourage it. I was startled, I confess, by the alteration in his
manners this morning; he did not speak like himself, and did not return
your kindness with any cordiality. But all this may be explained by
such a situation of his affairs as you have supposed. He had just
parted from my sister, had seen her leave him in the greatest
affliction; and if he felt obliged, from a fear of offending Mrs.
Smith, to resist the temptation of returning here soon, and yet aware
that by declining your invitation, by saying that he was going away for
some time, he should seem to act an ungenerous, a suspicious part by
our family, he might well be embarrassed and disturbed. In such a case,
a plain and open avowal of his difficulties would have been more to his
honour I think, as well as more consistent with his general
character; but I will not raise objections against any one s conduct on
so illiberal a foundation, as a difference in judgment from myself, or
a deviation from what I may think right and consistent.']
speaker: Elinor
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Marianne'], ['Marianne'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Elinor', 'Margaret', 'Marianne', 'Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby']]]

quoteText:
You speak very properly. Willoughby certainly does not deserve to be
suspected. Though _we_ have not known him long, he is no stranger in
this part of the world; and who has ever spoken to his disadvantage?
Had he been in a situation to act independently and marry immediately,
it might have been odd that he should leave us without acknowledging
everything to me at once: but this is not the case. It is an engagement
in some respects not prosperously begun, for their marriage must be at
a very uncertain distance; and even secrecy, as far as it can be
observed, may now be very advisable.
subQuotationList:
['You speak very properly. Willoughby certainly does not deserve to be
suspected. Though _we_ have not known him long, he is no stranger in
this part of the world; and who has ever spoken to his disadvantage?
Had he been in a situation to act independently and marry immediately,
it might have been odd that he should leave us without acknowledging
everything to me at once: but this is not the case. It is an engagement
in some respects not prosperously begun, for their marriage must be at
a very uncertain distance; and even secrecy, as far as it can be
observed, may now be very advisable.']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elinor'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Elinor', 'Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mrs. Dashwood', 'Marianne', 'Elinor', 'Margaret'], ['Marianne', 'Mr. Willoughby']]]

quoteText:
Remember, Elinor, how very often Sir John fetches our
letters himself from the post, and carries them to it. We have already
agreed that secrecy may be necessary, and we must acknowledge that it
could not be maintained if their correspondence were to pass through
Sir John s hands.
subQuotationList:
['Remember, Elinor,', 'how very often Sir John fetches our
letters himself from the post, and carries them to it. We have already
agreed that secrecy may be necessary, and we must acknowledge that it
could not be maintained if their correspondence were to pass through
Sir John s hands.']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elinor']], [['John Middleton'], ['Elinor', 'Margaret', 'Marianne', 'Mrs. Dashwood'], ['John Middleton'], ['Elinor', 'Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Elinor', 'Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Marianne', 'Mr. Willoughby'], ['John Middleton']]]

quoteText:
Why do you not ask Marianne at once, whether she is or she
is not engaged to Willoughby? From you, her mother, and so kind, so
indulgent a mother, the question could not give offence. It would be
the natural result of your affection for her. She used to be all
unreserve, and to you more especially.
subQuotationList:
['Why do you not ask Marianne at once,', 'whether she is or she
is not engaged to Willoughby? From you, her mother, and so kind, so
indulgent a mother, the question could not give offence. It would be
the natural result of your affection for her. She used to be all
unreserve, and to you more especially.']
speaker: Elinor
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Marianne']], [['Marianne'], ['Marianne'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Marianne'], ['Marianne'], ['Mrs. Dashwood']]]

quoteText:
I would not ask such a question for the world. Supposing it possible
that they are not engaged, what distress would not such an enquiry
inflict! At any rate it would be most ungenerous. I should never
deserve her confidence again, after forcing from her a confession of
what is meant at present to be unacknowledged to any one. I know
Marianne s heart: I know that she dearly loves me, and that I shall not
be the last to whom the affair is made known, when circumstances make
the revealment of it eligible. I would not attempt to force the
confidence of any one; of a child much less; because a sense of duty
would prevent the denial which her wishes might direct.
subQuotationList:
['I would not ask such a question for the world. Supposing it possible
that they are not engaged, what distress would not such an enquiry
inflict! At any rate it would be most ungenerous. I should never
deserve her confidence again, after forcing from her a confession of
what is meant at present to be unacknowledged to any one. I know
Marianne s heart: I know that she dearly loves me, and that I shall not
be the last to whom the affair is made known, when circumstances make
the revealment of it eligible. I would not attempt to force the
confidence of any one; of a child much less; because a sense of duty
would prevent the denial which her wishes might direct.']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood

quoteText:
We have never finished Hamlet, Marianne; our dear Willoughby went away
before we could get through it. We will put it by, that when he comes
again...But it may be months, perhaps, before _that_ happens.
subQuotationList: ['We have never finished Hamlet, Marianne; our dear Willoughby went away\nbefore we could get through it. We will put it by, that when he comes\nagain...But it may be months, perhaps, before _that_ happens.']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood
referringExpression: Mrs Dashwood accidentally taking up a volume of Shakespeare exclaimed
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Marianne', 'Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Marianne'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Marianne', 'Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Marianne', 'Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Mr. Willoughby']]]

quoteText: Months! No nor many weeks.
subQuotationList: ['Months!', 'No nor many weeks.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText: It is he; it is indeed; I know it is!
subQuotationList: ['It is he; it is indeed; I know it is!']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
Indeed, Marianne, I think you are mistaken. It is not Willoughby. The
person is not tall enough for him, and has not his air.
subQuotationList: ['Indeed, Marianne, I think you are mistaken. It is not Willoughby. The\nperson is not tall enough for him, and has not his air.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
He has, he has, I am sure he has. His air, his coat,
his horse. I knew how soon he would come.
subQuotationList: ['He has, he has,', 'I am sure he has. His air, his coat,\nhis horse. I knew how soon he would come.']
speaker: Marianne
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby']], [['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby']]]

quoteText: A fortnight!
subQuotationList: ['A fortnight!']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText: Have you been lately in Sussex?
subQuotationList: ['Have you been lately in Sussex?']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText: I was at Norland about a month ago.
subQuotationList: ['I was at Norland about a month ago.']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText: And how does dear, dear Norland look?
subQuotationList: ['And how does dear, dear Norland look?']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
Dear, dear Norland, probably looks much as it always
does at this time of the year. The woods and walks thickly covered with
dead leaves.
subQuotationList: ['Dear, dear Norland,', 'probably looks much as it always\ndoes at this time of the year. The woods and walks thickly covered with\ndead leaves.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Oh, with what transporting sensation have I formerly
seen them fall! How have I delighted, as I walked, to see them driven
in showers about me by the wind! What feelings have they, the season,
the air altogether inspired! Now there is no one to regard them. They
are seen only as a nuisance, swept hastily off, and driven as much as
possible from the sight.
subQuotationList:
['Oh,', 'with what transporting sensation have I formerly
seen them fall! How have I delighted, as I walked, to see them driven
in showers about me by the wind! What feelings have they, the season,
the air altogether inspired! Now there is no one to regard them. They
are seen only as a nuisance, swept hastily off, and driven as much as
possible from the sight.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
It is not every one, who has your passion for dead
leaves.
subQuotationList: ['It is not every one,', 'who has your passion for dead\nleaves.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
No; my feelings are not often shared, not often understood. But
_sometimes_ they are.
subQuotationList: ['No; my feelings are not often shared, not often understood. But\n_sometimes_ they are.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
Now, Edward, here is Barton valley. Look up
to it, and be tranquil if you can. Look at those hills! Did you ever
see their equals? To the left is Barton park, amongst those woods and
plantations. You may see the end of the house. And there, beneath that
farthest hill, which rises with such grandeur, is our cottage.
subQuotationList:
['Now, Edward,', 'here is Barton valley. Look up
to it, and be tranquil if you can. Look at those hills! Did you ever
see their equals? To the left is Barton park, amongst those woods and
plantations. You may see the end of the house. And there, beneath that
farthest hill, which rises with such grandeur, is our cottage.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
It is a beautiful country, but these bottoms must be
dirty in winter.
subQuotationList: ['It is a beautiful country,', 'but these bottoms must be\ndirty in winter.']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText: How can you think of dirt, with such objects before you?
subQuotationList: ['How can you think of dirt, with such objects before you?']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
Because, among the rest of the objects before
me, I see a very dirty lane.
subQuotationList: ['Because,', 'among the rest of the objects before\nme, I see a very dirty lane.']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText: How strange!
subQuotationList: ['How strange!']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
Have you an agreeable neighbourhood here? Are the Middletons pleasant
people?
subQuotationList: ['Have you an agreeable neighbourhood here? Are the Middletons pleasant\npeople?']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText:
No, not all, we could not be more unfortunately
situated.
subQuotationList: ['No, not all,', 'we could not be more unfortunately\nsituated.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
Marianne, how can you say so? How can you be so
unjust? They are a very respectable family, Mr. Ferrars; and towards us
have behaved in the friendliest manner. Have you forgot, Marianne, how
many pleasant days we have owed to them?
subQuotationList:
['Marianne,', 'how can you say so? How can you be so
unjust? They are a very respectable family, Mr. Ferrars; and towards us
have behaved in the friendliest manner. Have you forgot, Marianne, how
many pleasant days we have owed to them?']
speaker: Elinor
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Marianne']], [['Marianne'], ['Marianne'], ['Lady Middleton', 'John Middleton'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Elinor', 'Margaret', 'Marianne', 'Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Marianne'], ['Marianne'], ['Marianne', 'Elinor'], ['Lady Middleton', 'John Middleton']]]

quoteText: No, nor how many painful moments.
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'nor how many painful moments.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
What are Mrs. Ferrars s views for you at present, Edward? are you still
to be a great orator in spite of yourself?
subQuotationList: ['What are Mrs. Ferrars s views for you at present, Edward?', 'are you still\nto be a great orator in spite of yourself?']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood

quoteText:
No. I hope my mother is now convinced that I have no more talents than
inclination for a public life!
subQuotationList: ['No. I hope my mother is now convinced that I have no more talents than\ninclination for a public life!']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText:
But how is your fame to be established? for famous you must be to
satisfy all your family; and with no inclination for expense, no
affection for strangers, no profession, and no assurance, you may find
it a difficult matter.
subQuotationList:
['But how is your fame to be established? for famous you must be to
satisfy all your family; and with no inclination for expense, no
affection for strangers, no profession, and no assurance, you may find
it a difficult matter.']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood

quoteText:
I shall not attempt it. I have no wish to be distinguished; and have
every reason to hope I never shall. Thank Heaven! I cannot be forced
into genius and eloquence.
subQuotationList: ['I shall not attempt it. I have no wish to be distinguished; and have\nevery reason to hope I never shall. Thank Heaven! I cannot be forced\ninto genius and eloquence.']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText: You have no ambition, I well know. Your wishes are all moderate.
subQuotationList: ['You have no ambition, I well know. Your wishes are all moderate.']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood

quoteText:
As moderate as those of the rest of the world, I believe. I wish as
well as every body else to be perfectly happy; but, like every body
else it must be in my own way. Greatness will not make me so.
subQuotationList: ['As moderate as those of the rest of the world, I believe. I wish as\nwell as every body else to be perfectly happy; but, like every body\nelse it must be in my own way. Greatness will not make me so.']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText:
Strange that it would! What have wealth or grandeur
to do with happiness?
subQuotationList: ['Strange that it would!', 'What have wealth or grandeur\nto do with happiness?']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
Grandeur has but little, but wealth has much to do with
it.
subQuotationList: ['Grandeur has but little,', 'but wealth has much to do with\nit.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Elinor, for shame! money can only give happiness
where there is nothing else to give it. Beyond a competence, it can
afford no real satisfaction, as far as mere self is concerned.
subQuotationList: ['Elinor, for shame!', 'money can only give happiness\nwhere there is nothing else to give it. Beyond a competence, it can\nafford no real satisfaction, as far as mere self is concerned.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
Perhaps, we may come to the same point. _Your_
competence and _my_ wealth are very much alike, I dare say; and without
them, as the world goes now, we shall both agree that every kind of
external comfort must be wanting. Your ideas are only more noble than
mine. Come, what is your competence?
subQuotationList:
['Perhaps,', 'we may come to the same point. _Your_
competence and _my_ wealth are very much alike, I dare say; and without
them, as the world goes now, we shall both agree that every kind of
external comfort must be wanting. Your ideas are only more noble than
mine. Come, what is your competence?']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText: About eighteen hundred or two thousand a year; not more than _that_.
subQuotationList: ['About eighteen hundred or two thousand a year; not more than _that_.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
_two_ thousand a year! _one_ is my wealth! I guessed
how it would end.
subQuotationList: ['_two_ thousand a year! _one_ is my wealth! I guessed\nhow it would end.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
And yet two thousand a-year is a very moderate income, A family cannot well be maintained on a smaller. I am sure I am not
extravagant in my demands. A proper establishment of servants, a
carriage, perhaps two, and hunters, cannot be supported on less.
subQuotationList: ['And yet two thousand a-year is a very moderate income,', 'A family cannot well be maintained on a smaller. I am sure I am not\nextravagant in my demands. A proper establishment of servants, a\ncarriage, perhaps two, and hunters, cannot be supported on less.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
Hunters! but why must you have hunters? Every body
does not hunt.
subQuotationList: ['Hunters!', 'but why must you have hunters? Every body\ndoes not hunt.']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText: But most people do.
subQuotationList: ['But most people do.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
I wish, that somebody
would give us all a large fortune apiece!
subQuotationList: ['I wish,', 'that somebody\nwould give us all a large fortune apiece!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh that they would!
subQuotationList: ['Oh that they would!']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
We are all unanimous in that wish, I suppose, in spite
of the insufficiency of wealth.
subQuotationList: ['We are all unanimous in that wish, I suppose,', 'in spite\nof the insufficiency of wealth.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Oh dear! how happy I should be! I wonder what I
should do with it!
subQuotationList: ['Oh dear!', 'how happy I should be! I wonder what I\nshould do with it!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I should be puzzled to spend so large a fortune myself, if my children were all to be rich without my help.
subQuotationList: ['I should be puzzled to spend so large a fortune myself,', 'if my children were all to be rich without my help.']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood

quoteText:
You must begin your improvements on this house, and
your difficulties will soon vanish.
subQuotationList: ['You must begin your improvements on this house,', 'and\nyour difficulties will soon vanish.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
What magnificent orders would travel from this family to London, in such an event! What a happy day for booksellers,
music-sellers, and print-shops! You, Miss Dashwood, would give a
general commission for every new print of merit to be sent you and as
for Marianne, I know her greatness of soul, there would not be music
enough in London to content her. And books! Thomson, Cowper, Scott she
would buy them all over and over again: she would buy up every copy, I
believe, to prevent their falling into unworthy hands; and she would
have every book that tells her how to admire an old twisted tree.
Should not you, Marianne? Forgive me, if I am very saucy. But I was
willing to show you that I had not forgot our old disputes.
subQuotationList:
['What magnificent orders would travel from this family to London,', 'in such an event! What a happy day for booksellers,
music-sellers, and print-shops! You, Miss Dashwood, would give a
general commission for every new print of merit to be sent you and as
for Marianne, I know her greatness of soul, there would not be music
enough in London to content her. And books! Thomson, Cowper, Scott she
would buy them all over and over again: she would buy up every copy, I
believe, to prevent their falling into unworthy hands; and she would
have every book that tells her how to admire an old twisted tree.
Should not you, Marianne? Forgive me, if I am very saucy. But I was
willing to show you that I had not forgot our old disputes.']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText:
I love to be reminded of the past, Edward whether it be melancholy or
gay, I love to recall it and you will never offend me by talking of
former times. You are very right in supposing how my money would be
spent some of it, at least my loose cash would certainly be employed in
improving my collection of music and books.
subQuotationList:
['I love to be reminded of the past, Edward whether it be melancholy or
gay, I love to recall it and you will never offend me by talking of
former times. You are very right in supposing how my money would be
spent some of it, at least my loose cash would certainly be employed in
improving my collection of music and books.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
And the bulk of your fortune would be laid out in annuities on the
authors or their heirs.
subQuotationList: ['And the bulk of your fortune would be laid out in annuities on the\nauthors or their heirs.']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText: No, Edward, I should have something else to do with it.
subQuotationList: ['No, Edward, I should have something else to do with it.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
Perhaps, then, you would bestow it as a reward on that person who
wrote the ablest defence of your favourite maxim, that no one can ever
be in love more than once in their life your opinion on that point is
unchanged, I presume?
subQuotationList:
['Perhaps, then, you would bestow it as a reward on that person who
wrote the ablest defence of your favourite maxim, that no one can ever
be in love more than once in their life your opinion on that point is
unchanged, I presume?']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText:
Undoubtedly. At my time of life opinions are tolerably fixed. It is
not likely that I should now see or hear any thing to change them.
subQuotationList: ['Undoubtedly. At my time of life opinions are tolerably fixed. It is\nnot likely that I should now see or hear any thing to change them.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
Marianne is as steadfast as ever, you see, she is not
at all altered.
subQuotationList: ['Marianne is as steadfast as ever, you see,', 'she is not\nat all altered.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText: She is only grown a little more grave than she was.
subQuotationList: ['She is only grown a little more grave than she was.']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText:
Nay, Edward, _you_ need not reproach me. You are not
very gay yourself.
subQuotationList: ['Nay, Edward,', '_you_ need not reproach me. You are not\nvery gay yourself.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
Why should you think so! But gaiety never
was a part of _my_ character.
subQuotationList: ['Why should you think so!', 'But gaiety never\nwas a part of _my_ character.']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText:
Nor do I think it a part of Marianne s, I should hardly
call her a lively girl she is very earnest, very eager in all she
does sometimes talks a great deal and always with animation but she is
not often really merry.
subQuotationList:
['Nor do I think it a part of Marianne s,', 'I should hardly
call her a lively girl she is very earnest, very eager in all she
does sometimes talks a great deal and always with animation but she is
not often really merry.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
I believe you are right, and yet I have always set her
down as a lively girl.
subQuotationList: ['I believe you are right,', 'and yet I have always set her\ndown as a lively girl.']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText:
I have frequently detected myself in such kind of mistakes, in a total misapprehension of character in some point or
other: fancying people so much more gay or grave, or ingenious or
stupid than they really are, and I can hardly tell why or in what the
deception originated. Sometimes one is guided by what they say of
themselves, and very frequently by what other people say of them,
without giving oneself time to deliberate and judge.
subQuotationList:
['I have frequently detected myself in such kind of mistakes,', 'in a total misapprehension of character in some point or
other: fancying people so much more gay or grave, or ingenious or
stupid than they really are, and I can hardly tell why or in what the
deception originated. Sometimes one is guided by what they say of
themselves, and very frequently by what other people say of them,
without giving oneself time to deliberate and judge.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
But I thought it was right, Elinor, to be guided
wholly by the opinion of other people. I thought our judgments were
given us merely to be subservient to those of neighbours. This has
always been your doctrine, I am sure.
subQuotationList:
['But I thought it was right, Elinor,', 'to be guided
wholly by the opinion of other people. I thought our judgments were
given us merely to be subservient to those of neighbours. This has
always been your doctrine, I am sure.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
No, Marianne, never. My doctrine has never aimed at the subjection of
the understanding. All I have ever attempted to influence has been the
behaviour. You must not confound my meaning. I am guilty, I confess, of
having often wished you to treat our acquaintance in general with
greater attention; but when have I advised you to adopt their
sentiments or to conform to their judgment in serious matters?
subQuotationList:
['No, Marianne, never. My doctrine has never aimed at the subjection of
the understanding. All I have ever attempted to influence has been the
behaviour. You must not confound my meaning. I am guilty, I confess, of
having often wished you to treat our acquaintance in general with
greater attention; but when have I advised you to adopt their
sentiments or to conform to their judgment in serious matters?']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
You have not been able to bring your sister over to your plan of
general civility, Do you gain no ground?
subQuotationList: ['You have not been able to bring your sister over to your plan of\ngeneral civility,', 'Do you gain no ground?']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText: Quite the contrary,
subQuotationList: ['Quite the contrary,']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
My judgment, is all on your side of the question; but I
am afraid my practice is much more on your sister s. I never wish to
offend, but I am so foolishly shy, that I often seem negligent, when I
am only kept back by my natural awkwardness. I have frequently thought
that I must have been intended by nature to be fond of low company, I
am so little at my ease among strangers of gentility!
subQuotationList:
['My judgment,', 'is all on your side of the question; but I
am afraid my practice is much more on your sister s. I never wish to
offend, but I am so foolishly shy, that I often seem negligent, when I
am only kept back by my natural awkwardness. I have frequently thought
that I must have been intended by nature to be fond of low company, I
am so little at my ease among strangers of gentility!']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText: Marianne has not shyness to excuse any inattention of hers,
subQuotationList: ['Marianne has not shyness to excuse any inattention of hers,']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
She knows her own worth too well for false shame, Shyness is only the effect of a sense of inferiority in some way or
other. If I could persuade myself that my manners were perfectly easy
and graceful, I should not be shy.
subQuotationList: ['She knows her own worth too well for false shame,', 'Shyness is only the effect of a sense of inferiority in some way or\nother. If I could persuade myself that my manners were perfectly easy\nand graceful, I should not be shy.']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText: But you would still be reserved, and that is worse.
subQuotationList: ['But you would still be reserved,', 'and that is worse.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText: Reserved! Am I reserved, Marianne?
subQuotationList: ['Reserved! Am I reserved, Marianne?']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText: Yes, very.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, very.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
I do not understand you, Reserved! how, in
what manner? What am I to tell you? What can you suppose?
subQuotationList: ['I do not understand you,', 'Reserved! how, in\nwhat manner? What am I to tell you? What can you suppose?']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText:
Do not you know my sister well enough to
understand what she means? Do not you know she calls every one reserved
who does not talk as fast, and admire what she admires as rapturously
as herself?
subQuotationList:
['Do not you know my sister well enough to
understand what she means? Do not you know she calls every one reserved
who does not talk as fast, and admire what she admires as rapturously
as herself?']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
I am going into the village to see my horses, as you are
not yet ready for breakfast; I shall be back again presently.
subQuotationList: ['I am going into the village to see my horses,', 'as you are\nnot yet ready for breakfast; I shall be back again presently.']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText:
You
must not enquire too far, Marianne remember I have no knowledge in the
picturesque, and I shall offend you by my ignorance and want of taste
if we come to particulars. I shall call hills steep, which ought to be
bold; surfaces strange and uncouth, which ought to be irregular and
