rugged; and distant objects out of sight, which ought only to be
indistinct through the soft medium of a hazy atmosphere. You must be
satisfied with such admiration as I can honestly give. I call it a very
fine country the hills are steep, the woods seem full of fine timber,
and the valley looks comfortable and snug with rich meadows and several
neat farm houses scattered here and there. It exactly answers my idea
of a fine country, because it unites beauty with utility and I dare say
it is a picturesque one too, because you admire it; I can easily
believe it to be full of rocks and promontories, grey moss and brush
wood, but these are all lost on me. I know nothing of the picturesque.
subQuotationList:
['You
must not enquire too far, Marianne remember I have no knowledge in the
picturesque, and I shall offend you by my ignorance and want of taste
if we come to particulars. I shall call hills steep, which ought to be
bold; surfaces strange and uncouth, which ought to be irregular and
rugged; and distant objects out of sight, which ought only to be
indistinct through the soft medium of a hazy atmosphere. You must be
satisfied with such admiration as I can honestly give. I call it a very
fine country the hills are steep, the woods seem full of fine timber,
and the valley looks comfortable and snug with rich meadows and several
neat farm houses scattered here and there. It exactly answers my idea
of a fine country, because it unites beauty with utility and I dare say
it is a picturesque one too, because you admire it; I can easily
believe it to be full of rocks and promontories, grey moss and brush
wood, but these are all lost on me. I know nothing of the picturesque.']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText:
I am afraid it is but too true, but why should you
boast of it?
subQuotationList: ['I am afraid it is but too true,', 'but why should you\nboast of it?']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
I suspect, that to avoid one kind of affectation,
Edward here falls into another. Because he believes many people pretend
to more admiration of the beauties of nature than they really feel, and
is disgusted with such pretensions, he affects greater indifference and
less discrimination in viewing them himself than he possesses. He is
fastidious and will have an affectation of his own.
subQuotationList:
['I suspect,', 'that to avoid one kind of affectation,
Edward here falls into another. Because he believes many people pretend
to more admiration of the beauties of nature than they really feel, and
is disgusted with such pretensions, he affects greater indifference and
less discrimination in viewing them himself than he possesses. He is
fastidious and will have an affectation of his own.']
speaker: Elinor
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars']]]

quoteText:
It is very true, that admiration of landscape scenery
is become a mere jargon. Every body pretends to feel and tries to
describe with the taste and elegance of him who first defined what
picturesque beauty was. I detest jargon of every kind, and sometimes I
have kept my feelings to myself, because I could find no language to
describe them in but what was worn and hackneyed out of all sense and
meaning.
subQuotationList:
['It is very true,', 'that admiration of landscape scenery
is become a mere jargon. Every body pretends to feel and tries to
describe with the taste and elegance of him who first defined what
picturesque beauty was. I detest jargon of every kind, and sometimes I
have kept my feelings to myself, because I could find no language to
describe them in but what was worn and hackneyed out of all sense and
meaning.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
I am convinced, that you really feel all the delight in
a fine prospect which you profess to feel. But, in return, your sister
must allow me to feel no more than I profess. I like a fine prospect,
but not on picturesque principles. I do not like crooked, twisted,
blasted trees. I admire them much more if they are tall, straight, and
flourishing. I do not like ruined, tattered cottages. I am not fond of
nettles or thistles, or heath blossoms. I have more pleasure in a snug
farm-house than a watch-tower and a troop of tidy, happy villagers
please me better than the finest banditti in the world.
subQuotationList:
['I am convinced,', 'that you really feel all the delight in
a fine prospect which you profess to feel. But, in return, your sister
must allow me to feel no more than I profess. I like a fine prospect,
but not on picturesque principles. I do not like crooked, twisted,
blasted trees. I admire them much more if they are tall, straight, and
flourishing. I do not like ruined, tattered cottages. I am not fond of
nettles or thistles, or heath blossoms. I have more pleasure in a snug
farm-house than a watch-tower and a troop of tidy, happy villagers
please me better than the finest banditti in the world.']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText:
I never saw you wear a ring before, Edward, Is that
Fanny s hair? I remember her promising to give you some. But I should
have thought her hair had been darker.
subQuotationList: ['I never saw you wear a ring before, Edward,', 'Is that\nFanny s hair? I remember her promising to give you some. But I should\nhave thought her hair had been darker.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
Yes; it is my sister s hair. The
setting always casts a different shade on it, you know.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; it is my sister s hair. The\nsetting always casts a different shade on it, you know.']
speaker: Edward Ferrars
referringExpression: He coloured very deeply and giving a momentary glance at Elinor replied

quoteText:
You _must_ drink tea with us to night, for we shall be
quite alone and tomorrow you must absolutely dine with us, for we shall
be a large party.
subQuotationList: ['You _must_ drink tea with us to night,', 'for we shall be\nquite alone and tomorrow you must absolutely dine with us, for we shall\nbe a large party.']
speaker: John Middleton
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Marianne'], ['Lady Middleton', 'Mrs. Jennings', 'John Middleton']], [['Lady Middleton', 'Mrs. Jennings', 'John Middleton'], ['Marianne'], ['Lady Middleton', 'Mrs. Jennings', 'John Middleton'], ['Lady Middleton', 'Mrs. Jennings', 'John Middleton']]]

quoteText:
And who knows but you may raise
a dance, And that will tempt _you_, Miss Marianne.
subQuotationList: ['And who knows but you may raise\na dance,', 'And that will tempt _you_, Miss Marianne.']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText: A dance! Impossible! Who is to dance?
subQuotationList: ['A dance!', 'Impossible! Who is to dance?']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText:
Who! why yourselves, and the Careys, and Whitakers to be sure. What!
you thought nobody could dance because a certain person that shall be
nameless is gone!
subQuotationList: ['Who! why yourselves, and the Careys, and Whitakers to be sure. What!\nyou thought nobody could dance because a certain person that shall be\nnameless is gone!']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText:
I wish with all my soul, that Willoughby were among
us again.
subQuotationList: ['I wish with all my soul,', 'that Willoughby were among\nus again.']
speaker: John Middleton

quoteText:
And who
is Willoughby?
subQuotationList: ['And who\nis Willoughby?']
speaker: Edward Ferrars
referringExpression: said he in a low voice to Miss Dashwood

quoteText: I have been guessing. Shall I tell you my guess?
subQuotationList: ['I have been guessing. Shall I tell you my guess?']
speaker: Edward Ferrars
referringExpression: he went immediately round her and said

quoteText: What do you mean?
subQuotationList: ['What do you mean?']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText: Shall I tell you?
subQuotationList: ['Shall I tell you?']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText: Certainly.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText: Well then; I guess that Mr. Willoughby hunts.
subQuotationList: ['Well then; I guess that Mr. Willoughby hunts.']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText:
Oh, Edward! How can you? But the time will come I hope...I am sure you
will like him.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Edward! How can you? But the time will come I hope...I am sure you\nwill like him.']
speaker: Marianne
referringExpression: she could not help smiling at the quiet archness of his manner and after a moment s silence said

quoteText: I do not doubt it,
subQuotationList: ['I do not doubt it,']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText:
I think, Edward, you would be a happier man if you had any profession to
engage your time and give an interest to your plans and actions. Some
inconvenience to your friends, indeed, might result from it you would
not be able to give them so much of your time. But you
would be materially benefited in one particular at least you would know
where to go when you left them."
subQuotationList:
['I think, Edward,', 'you would be a happier man if you had any profession to
engage your time and give an interest to your plans and actions. Some
inconvenience to your friends, indeed, might result from it you would
not be able to give them so much of your time. But', 'you
would be materially benefited in one particular at least you would know
where to go when you left them."']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Edward Ferrars']], [['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars']], [['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars']]]

quoteText:
I do assure you, that I have long thought on this point,
as you think now. It has been, and is, and probably will always be a
heavy misfortune to me, that I have had no necessary business to engage
me, no profession to give me employment, or afford me any thing like
independence. But unfortunately my own nicety, and the nicety of my
friends, have made me what I am, an idle, helpless being. We never
could agree in our choice of a profession. I always preferred the
church, as I still do. But that was not smart enough for my family.
They recommended the army. That was a great deal too smart for me. The
law was allowed to be genteel enough; many young men, who had chambers
in the Temple, made a very good appearance in the first circles, and
drove about town in very knowing gigs. But I had no inclination for the
law, even in this less abstruse study of it, which my family approved.
As for the navy, it had fashion on its side, but I was too old when the
subject was first started to enter it and, at length, as there was no
necessity for my having any profession at all, as I might be as dashing
and expensive without a red coat on my back as with one, idleness was
pronounced on the whole to be most advantageous and honourable, and a
young man of eighteen is not in general so earnestly bent on being busy
as to resist the solicitations of his friends to do nothing. I was
therefore entered at Oxford and have been properly idle ever since.
subQuotationList:
['I do assure you,', 'that I have long thought on this point,
as you think now. It has been, and is, and probably will always be a
heavy misfortune to me, that I have had no necessary business to engage
me, no profession to give me employment, or afford me any thing like
independence. But unfortunately my own nicety, and the nicety of my
friends, have made me what I am, an idle, helpless being. We never
could agree in our choice of a profession. I always preferred the
church, as I still do. But that was not smart enough for my family.
They recommended the army. That was a great deal too smart for me. The
law was allowed to be genteel enough; many young men, who had chambers
in the Temple, made a very good appearance in the first circles, and
drove about town in very knowing gigs. But I had no inclination for the
law, even in this less abstruse study of it, which my family approved.
As for the navy, it had fashion on its side, but I was too old when the
subject was first started to enter it and, at length, as there was no
necessity for my having any profession at all, as I might be as dashing
and expensive without a red coat on my back as with one, idleness was
pronounced on the whole to be most advantageous and honourable, and a
young man of eighteen is not in general so earnestly bent on being busy
as to resist the solicitations of his friends to do nothing. I was
therefore entered at Oxford and have been properly idle ever since.']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText:
The consequence of which, I suppose, will be, since leisure has not promoted your own happiness, that your sons will
be brought up to as many pursuits, employments, professions, and trades
as Columella s.
subQuotationList: ['The consequence of which, I suppose, will be,', 'since leisure has not promoted your own happiness, that your sons will\nbe brought up to as many pursuits, employments, professions, and trades\nas Columella s.']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood

quoteText:
They will be brought up, to be as
unlike myself as is possible. In feeling, in action, in condition, in
every thing.
subQuotationList: ['They will be brought up,', 'to be as\nunlike myself as is possible. In feeling, in action, in condition, in\nevery thing.']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText:
Come, come; this is all an effusion of immediate want of spirits,
Edward. You are in a melancholy humour, and fancy that any one unlike
yourself must be happy. But remember that the pain of parting from
friends will be felt by every body at times, whatever be their
education or state. Know your own happiness. You want nothing but
patience or give it a more fascinating name, call it hope. Your mother
will secure to you, in time, that independence you are so anxious for;
it is her duty, and it will, it must ere long become her happiness to
prevent your whole youth from being wasted in discontent. How much may
not a few months do?
subQuotationList:
['Come, come; this is all an effusion of immediate want of spirits,
Edward. You are in a melancholy humour, and fancy that any one unlike
yourself must be happy. But remember that the pain of parting from
friends will be felt by every body at times, whatever be their
education or state. Know your own happiness. You want nothing but
patience or give it a more fascinating name, call it hope. Your mother
will secure to you, in time, that independence you are so anxious for;
it is her duty, and it will, it must ere long become her happiness to
prevent your whole youth from being wasted in discontent. How much may
not a few months do?']
speaker: Mrs. Dashwood
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Mrs. Ferrars'], ['Mrs. Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars']]]

quoteText:
I think, that I may defy many months to produce any
good to me.
subQuotationList: ['I think,', 'that I may defy many months to produce any\ngood to me.']
speaker: Edward Ferrars

quoteText:
Well, we have brought you some strangers. How do you like
them?
subQuotationList: ['Well,', 'we have brought you some strangers. How do you like\nthem?']
speaker: John Middleton

quoteText: Hush! they will hear you.
subQuotationList: ['Hush! they will hear you.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Never mind if they do. It is only the Palmers. Charlotte is very
pretty, I can tell you. You may see her if you look this way.
subQuotationList: ['Never mind if they do. It is only the Palmers. Charlotte is very\npretty, I can tell you. You may see her if you look this way.']
speaker: John Middleton

quoteText:
Where is Marianne? Has she run away because we are come? I see her
instrument is open.
subQuotationList: ['Where is Marianne? Has she run away because we are come? I see her\ninstrument is open.']
speaker: John Middleton

quoteText: She is walking, I believe.
subQuotationList: ['She is walking, I believe.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
"How do you do, my dear? How does Mrs.
Dashwood do? And where are your sisters? What! all alone! you will be
glad of a little company to sit with you. I have brought my other son
and daughter to see you. Only think of their coming so suddenly! I
thought I heard a carriage last night, while we were drinking our tea,
but it never entered my head that it could be them. I thought of
nothing but whether it might not be Colonel Brandon come back again; so
I said to Sir John

quoteText:
Well! what a delightful room this is! I never saw anything so
charming! Only think, Mama, how it is improved since I was here last! I
always thought it such a sweet place, ma am! (turning to Mrs. Dashwood)
but you have made it so charming! Only look, sister, how delightful
every thing is! How I should like such a house for myself! Should not
you, Mr. Palmer?
subQuotationList:
['Well! what a delightful room this is! I never saw anything so

you, Mr. Palmer?']
speaker: Charlotte
referringExpression: Mrs Palmer on the contrary who was strongly endowed by nature with a turn for being uniformly civil and happy was hardly seated before her admiration of the parlour and every thing in it burst forth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Mrs. Dashwood'], ['Lady Middleton'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Palmer']]]

quoteText:
Mr. Palmer does not hear me, he never does
sometimes. It is so ridiculous!
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Palmer does not hear me,', 'he never does\nsometimes. It is so ridiculous!']
speaker: Charlotte

quoteText:
You may believe how glad we all were to see them, but, however, I can t help wishing they
had not travelled quite so fast, nor made such a long journey of it,
for they came all round by London upon account of some business, for
you know it was
wrong in her situation. I wanted her to stay at home and rest this
morning, but she would come with us; she longed so much to see you
all!"
subQuotationList:
['You may believe how glad we all were to see them,', 'but, however, I can t help wishing they
had not travelled quite so fast, nor made such a long journey of it,
for they came all round by London upon account of some business, for
you know', 'it was
wrong in her situation. I wanted her to stay at home and rest this

speaker: Mrs. Jennings
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elinor'], ['Lady Middleton', 'Mrs. Jennings', 'John Middleton'], ['Charlotte', 'Mr. Palmer']], [['Charlotte', 'Mr. Palmer'], ['Charlotte', 'Mr. Palmer']], [['Charlotte'], ['Charlotte'], ['Charlotte'], ['Mrs. Jennings', 'John Middleton'], ['Charlotte'], ['Elinor', 'Mrs. Dashwood', 'Margaret', 'Marianne']]]

quoteText: She expects to be confined in February,
subQuotationList: ['She expects to be confined in February,']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText: No, none at all,
subQuotationList: ['No, none at all,']
speaker: Mr. Palmer

quoteText:
Here comes Marianne, Now, Palmer, you shall see a
monstrous pretty girl.
subQuotationList: ['Here comes Marianne,', 'Now, Palmer, you shall see a\nmonstrous pretty girl.']
speaker: John Middleton

quoteText:
Oh! dear, how beautiful these are! Well! how delightful! Do but look,
mama, how sweet! I declare they are quite charming; I could look at
them for ever.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! dear, how beautiful these are! Well! how delightful! Do but look,\nmama, how sweet! I declare they are quite charming; I could look at\nthem for ever.']
speaker: Charlotte

quoteText: My love, have you been asleep?
subQuotationList: ['My love, have you been asleep?']
speaker: Charlotte

quoteText:
Why should they ask us? The rent of this cottage is said to be low; but we have it on very
hard terms, if we are to dine at the park whenever any one is staying
either with them, or with us.
subQuotationList: ['Why should they ask us?', 'The rent of this cottage is said to be low; but we have it on very\nhard terms, if we are to dine at the park whenever any one is staying\neither with them, or with us.']
speaker: Marianne
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Charlotte', 'John Middleton', 'Lady Middleton', 'Mrs. Jennings'], ['Marianne', 'Elinor']], [['Mrs. Dashwood', 'Marianne', 'Elinor', 'Margaret'], ['Mrs. Dashwood', 'Marianne', 'Elinor', 'Margaret'], ['Lady Middleton', 'John Middleton'], ['Mrs. Dashwood', 'Marianne', 'Elinor', 'Margaret']]]

quoteText:
They mean no less to be civil and kind to us now, by
these frequent invitations, than by those which we received from them a
few weeks ago. The alteration is not in them, if their parties are
grown tedious and dull. We must look for the change elsewhere.
subQuotationList:
['They mean no less to be civil and kind to us now,', 'by
these frequent invitations, than by those which we received from them a
few weeks ago. The alteration is not in them, if their parties are
grown tedious and dull. We must look for the change elsewhere.']
speaker: Elinor
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Lady Middleton', 'John Middleton'], ['Marianne', 'Elinor']], [['Marianne', 'Elinor'], ['Lady Middleton', 'John Middleton'], ['Lady Middleton', 'John Middleton'], ['Lady Middleton', 'John Middleton'], ['Marianne', 'Elinor']]]

quoteText:
I am so glad to see you! for it is so bad a day I was afraid you might not come,
which would be a shocking thing, as we go away again tomorrow. We must
go, for the Westons come to us next week you know. It was quite a
sudden thing our coming at all, and I knew nothing of it till the
carriage was coming to the door, and then Mr. Palmer asked me if I
would go with him to Barton. He is so droll! He never tells me any
thing! I am so sorry we cannot stay longer; however we shall meet again
in town very soon, I hope.
subQuotationList:
['I am so glad to see you!', 'for it is so bad a day I was afraid you might not come,
which would be a shocking thing, as we go away again tomorrow. We must
go, for the Westons come to us next week you know. It was quite a
sudden thing our coming at all, and I knew nothing of it till the

speaker: Charlotte
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Marianne', 'Elinor']], [['Marianne', 'Elinor'], ['Charlotte', 'Mr. Palmer'], ['Charlotte', 'Mr. Palmer'], ['Charlotte', 'Mr. Palmer'], ['Elinor', 'Marianne'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Charlotte', 'Mr. Palmer'], ['Charlotte', 'Marianne', 'Elinor']]]

quoteText:
Not go to town! I shall be quite
disappointed if you do not. I could get the nicest house in the world
for you, next door to ours, in Hanover-square. You must come, indeed. I
am sure I shall be very happy to chaperon you at any time till I am
confined, if Mrs. Dashwood should not like to go into public.
subQuotationList:
['Not go to town!', 'I shall be quite
disappointed if you do not. I could get the nicest house in the world
for you, next door to ours, in Hanover-square. You must come, indeed. I
am sure I shall be very happy to chaperon you at any time till I am
confined, if Mrs. Dashwood should not like to go into public.']
speaker: Charlotte

quoteText:
Oh, my love, you must help me to persuade the Miss Dashwoods to go to town
this winter.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, my love,', 'you must help me to persuade the Miss Dashwoods to go to town\nthis winter.']
speaker: Charlotte
referringExpression: cried Mrs Palmer to her husband

quoteText:
How horrid all this is! Such weather makes every thing and
every body disgusting. Dullness is as much produced within doors as
without, by rain. It makes one detest all one s acquaintance. What the
devil does Sir John mean by not having a billiard room in his house?
How few people know what comfort is! Sir John is as stupid as the
weather.
subQuotationList:
['How horrid all this is!', 'Such weather makes every thing and
every body disgusting. Dullness is as much produced within doors as
without, by rain. It makes one detest all one s acquaintance. What the
devil does Sir John mean by not having a billiard room in his house?
How few people know what comfort is! Sir John is as stupid as the
weather.']
speaker: Mr. Palmer

quoteText:
I am afraid, Miss Marianne, you have not been able to
take your usual walk to Allenham today.
subQuotationList: ['I am afraid, Miss Marianne,', 'you have not been able to\ntake your usual walk to Allenham today.']
speaker: John Middleton

quoteText:
Oh, don t be so sly before us, for we know all
about it, I assure you; and I admire your taste very much, for I think
he is extremely handsome. We do not live a great way from him in the
country, you know. Not above ten miles, I dare say.
subQuotationList:
['Oh, don t be so sly before us,', 'for we know all
about it, I assure you; and I admire your taste very much, for I think
he is extremely handsome. We do not live a great way from him in the
country, you know. Not above ten miles, I dare say.']
speaker: Charlotte

quoteText: Much nearer thirty,
subQuotationList: ['Much nearer thirty,']
speaker: Mr. Palmer

quoteText:
Ah, well! there is not much difference. I never was at his house; but
they say it is a sweet pretty place.
subQuotationList: ['Ah, well! there is not much difference. I never was at his house; but\nthey say it is a sweet pretty place.']
speaker: Charlotte

quoteText: As vile a spot as I ever saw in my life,
subQuotationList: ['As vile a spot as I ever saw in my life,']
speaker: Mr. Palmer

quoteText:
Is it very ugly? then it must be some other
place that is so pretty I suppose.
subQuotationList: ['Is it very ugly?', 'then it must be some other\nplace that is so pretty I suppose.']
speaker: Charlotte

quoteText:
My dear, it is very provoking that we should be
so few. Why did not you ask the Gilberts to come to us today?
subQuotationList: ['My dear,', 'it is very provoking that we should be\nso few. Why did not you ask the Gilberts to come to us today?']
speaker: John Middleton
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Lady Middleton']], [['Charlotte', 'Elinor', 'Marianne', 'John Middleton', 'Mrs. Jennings', 'Mr. Palmer', 'Lady Middleton'], ['Lady Middleton'], ['Elinor', 'Marianne', 'John Middleton', 'Mrs. Jennings', 'Mr. Palmer', 'Lady Middleton']]]

quoteText:
Did not I tell you, Sir John, when you spoke to me about it before,
that it could not be done? They dined with us last.
subQuotationList: ['Did not I tell you, Sir John, when you spoke to me about it before,\nthat it could not be done? They dined with us last.']
speaker: Lady Middleton
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Middleton'], ['John Middleton'], ['John Middleton'], ['John Middleton'], ['Lady Middleton', 'John Middleton']]]

quoteText:
You and I, Sir John, should not stand upon such
ceremony.
subQuotationList: ['You and I, Sir John,', 'should not stand upon such\nceremony.']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText: Then you would be very ill-bred,
subQuotationList: ['Then you would be very ill-bred,']
speaker: Mr. Palmer

quoteText: My love you contradict every body, Do you know that you are quite rude?
subQuotationList: ['My love you contradict every body,', 'Do you know that you are quite rude?']
speaker: Charlotte

quoteText:
I did not know I contradicted any body in calling your mother
ill-bred.
subQuotationList: ['I did not know I contradicted any body in calling your mother\nill-bred.']
speaker: Mr. Palmer

quoteText:
Ay, you may abuse me as you please, you have taken Charlotte off my hands, and cannot give her back again.
So there I have the whip hand of you.
subQuotationList: ['Ay, you may abuse me as you please,', 'you have taken Charlotte off my hands, and cannot give her back again.\nSo there I have the whip hand of you.']
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

quoteText:
Mr. Palmer is so droll! He is
always out of humour.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Palmer is so droll!', 'He is\nalways out of humour.']
speaker: Charlotte
referringExpression: said she in a whisper to Elinor

quoteText:
Oh, my dear Miss Dashwood, I have
got such a favour to ask of you and your sister. Will you come and
spend some time at Cleveland this Christmas? Now, pray do, and come
while the Westons are with us. You cannot think how happy I shall be!
It will be quite delightful! My love, don t
you long to have the Miss Dashwoods come to Cleveland?
subQuotationList:
['Oh, my dear Miss Dashwood,', 'I have
got such a favour to ask of you and your sister. Will you come and
spend some time at Cleveland this Christmas? Now, pray do, and come
while the Westons are with us. You cannot think how happy I shall be!
It will be quite delightful! My love,', 'don t
you long to have the Miss Dashwoods come to Cleveland?']
speaker: Charlotte
mentionTextsList: [['my dear Miss Dashwood'], ['you', 'your sister.', 'you', 'us', 'You', 'My love'], ['the Miss Dashwoods']]

quoteText:
Certainly, I came into Devonshire with no
other view.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly,', 'I came into Devonshire with no\nother view.']
speaker: Mr. Palmer

quoteText:
There now, you see Mr. Palmer expects you; so you
cannot refuse to come.
subQuotationList: ['There now,', 'you see Mr. Palmer expects you; so you\ncannot refuse to come.']
speaker: Charlotte

quoteText:
But indeed you must and shall come. I am sure you will like it of all
things. The Westons will be with us, and it will be quite delightful.
You cannot think what a sweet place Cleveland is; and we are so gay
now, for Mr. Palmer is always going about the country canvassing
against the election; and so many people came to dine with us that I
never saw before, it is quite charming! But, poor fellow! it is very
fatiguing to him! for he is forced to make every body like him.
subQuotationList:
['But indeed you must and shall come. I am sure you will like it of all
things. The Westons will be with us, and it will be quite delightful.
You cannot think what a sweet place Cleveland is; and we are so gay
now, for Mr. Palmer is always going about the country canvassing
against the election; and so many people came to dine with us that I
never saw before, it is quite charming! But, poor fellow! it is very
fatiguing to him! for he is forced to make every body like him.']
speaker: Charlotte
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Marianne', 'Elinor'], ['Marianne', 'Elinor'], ['Charlotte', 'Mr. Palmer'], ['Charlotte', 'Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Charlotte', 'Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Palmer']]]

quoteText:
How charming it will be, when he is in
Parliament! won t it? How I shall laugh! It will be so ridiculous to
see all his letters directed to him with an M.P. But do you know, he
says, he will never frank for me? He declares he won t. Don t you, Mr.
Palmer?
subQuotationList:
['How charming it will be,', 'when he is in
Parliament! won t it? How I shall laugh! It will be so ridiculous to
see all his letters directed to him with an M.P. But do you know, he
says, he will never frank for me? He declares he won t. Don t you, Mr.
Palmer?']
speaker: Charlotte
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Marianne', 'Elinor'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Palmer']]]

quoteText:
He cannot bear writing, you know, he says it is quite
shocking.
subQuotationList: ['He cannot bear writing, you know,', 'he says it is quite\nshocking.']
speaker: Charlotte

quoteText:
No, I never said any thing so irrational. Don t palm all
your abuses of language upon me.
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'I never said any thing so irrational. Don t palm all\nyour abuses of language upon me.']
speaker: Mr. Palmer

quoteText:
There now; you see how droll he is. This is always the way with him!
Sometimes he won t speak to me for half a day together, and then he
comes out with something so droll all about any thing in the world.
subQuotationList: ['There now; you see how droll he is. This is always the way with him!\nSometimes he won t speak to me for half a day together, and then he\ncomes out with something so droll all about any thing in the world.']
speaker: Charlotte

quoteText: Certainly, he seems very agreeable.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly,', 'he seems very agreeable.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Well I am so glad you do. I thought you would, he is so pleasant; and
Mr. Palmer is excessively pleased with you and your sisters I can tell
you, and you can t think how disappointed he will be if you don t come
to Cleveland. I can t imagine why you should object to it.
subQuotationList:
['Well I am so glad you do. I thought you would, he is so pleasant; and
Mr. Palmer is excessively pleased with you and your sisters I can tell
you, and you can t think how disappointed he will be if you don t come
to Cleveland. I can t imagine why you should object to it.']
speaker: Charlotte

quoteText:
Oh dear, yes; I know him extremely well, Not
that I ever spoke to him, indeed; but I have seen him for ever in town.
Somehow or other I never happened to be staying at Barton while he was
at Allenham. Mama saw him here once before; but I was with my uncle at
Weymouth. However, I dare say we should have seen a great deal of him
in Somersetshire, if it had not happened very unluckily that we should
never have been in the country together. He is very little at Combe, I
believe; but if he were ever so much there, I do not think Mr. Palmer
would visit him, for he is in the opposition, you know, and besides it
is such a way off. I know why you inquire about him, very well; your
sister is to marry him. I am monstrous glad of it, for then I shall
have her for a neighbour you know.
subQuotationList:
['Oh dear, yes; I know him extremely well,', 'Not
that I ever spoke to him, indeed; but I have seen him for ever in town.
Somehow or other I never happened to be staying at Barton while he was

speaker: Charlotte
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Willoughby']], [['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Charlotte', 'Mr. Palmer'], ['Charlotte'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Elinor'], ['Elinor'], ['Marianne'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Marianne'], ['Elinor']]]

quoteText:
Upon my word, you know much more of the matter than
I do, if you have any reason to expect such a match.
subQuotationList: ['Upon my word,', 'you know much more of the matter than\nI do, if you have any reason to expect such a match.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Don t pretend to deny it, because you know it is what every body talks
of. I assure you I heard of it in my way through town.
subQuotationList: ['Don t pretend to deny it, because you know it is what every body talks\nof. I assure you I heard of it in my way through town.']
speaker: Charlotte

quoteText: My dear Mrs. Palmer!
subQuotationList: ['My dear Mrs. Palmer!']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Upon my honour I did. I met Colonel Brandon Monday morning in
Bond-street, just before we left town, and he told me of it directly.
subQuotationList: ['Upon my honour I did. I met Colonel Brandon Monday morning in\nBond-street, just before we left town, and he told me of it directly.']
speaker: Charlotte

quoteText:
You surprise me very much. Colonel Brandon tell you of it! Surely you
must be mistaken. To give such intelligence to a person who could not
be interested in it, even if it were true, is not what I should expect
Colonel Brandon to do.
subQuotationList:
['You surprise me very much. Colonel Brandon tell you of it! Surely you
must be mistaken. To give such intelligence to a person who could not
be interested in it, even if it were true, is not what I should expect
Colonel Brandon to do.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
But I do assure you it was so, for all that, and I will tell you how
it happened. When we met him, he turned back and walked with us; and so
we began talking of my brother and sister, and one thing and another,
and I said to him,  So, Colonel, there is a new family come to Barton
cottage, I hear, and mama sends me word they are very pretty, and that
one of them is going to be married to Mr. Willoughby of Combe Magna. Is
it true, pray? for of course you must know, as you have been in
Devonshire so lately.
subQuotationList:
['But I do assure you it was so, for all that, and I will tell you how
it happened. When we met him, he turned back and walked with us; and so
we began talking of my brother and sister, and one thing and another,
and I said to him,  So, Colonel, there is a new family come to Barton
cottage, I hear, and mama sends me word they are very pretty, and that
one of them is going to be married to Mr. Willoughby of Combe Magna. Is
it true, pray? for of course you must know, as you have been in
Devonshire so lately.']
speaker: Charlotte
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elinor'], ['Elinor'], ['Charlotte', 'Mr. Palmer'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Charlotte', 'Mr. Palmer'], ['Charlotte', 'Colonel Brandon', 'Mr. Palmer'], ['John Middleton'], ['Lady Middleton'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon']]]

quoteText: And what did the Colonel say?
subQuotationList: ['And what did the Colonel say?']
speaker: Elinor

subQuotationList: ['Oh he did not say much; but he looked as if he knew it to be true, so\nfrom that moment I set it down as certain. It will be quite delightful,\nI declare! When is it to take place?']
speaker: Charlotte

quoteText: Mr. Brandon was very well I hope?
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Brandon was very well I hope?']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Oh! yes, quite well; and so full of your praises, he did nothing but
say fine things of you.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! yes, quite well; and so full of your praises, he did nothing but\nsay fine things of you.']
speaker: Charlotte

quoteText:
I am flattered by his commendation. He seems an excellent man; and I
think him uncommonly pleasing.
subQuotationList: ['I am flattered by his commendation. He seems an excellent man; and I\nthink him uncommonly pleasing.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
So do I. He is such a charming man, that it is quite a pity he should
be so grave and so dull. Mama says _he_ was in love with your sister
too. I assure you it was a great compliment if he was, for he hardly
ever falls in love with any body.
subQuotationList:
['So do I. He is such a charming man, that it is quite a pity he should
be so grave and so dull. Mama says _he_ was in love with your sister
too. I assure you it was a great compliment if he was, for he hardly
ever falls in love with any body.']
speaker: Charlotte

quoteText: Is Mr. Willoughby much known in your part of Somersetshire?
subQuotationList: ['Is Mr. Willoughby much known in your part of Somersetshire?']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Oh! yes, extremely well; that is, I do not believe many people are
acquainted with him, because Combe Magna is so far off; but they all
think him extremely agreeable I assure you. Nobody is more liked than
Mr. Willoughby wherever he goes, and so you may tell your sister. She
is a monstrous lucky girl to get him, upon my honour; not but that he
is much more lucky in getting her, because she is so very handsome and
agreeable, that nothing can be good enough for her. However, I don t
think her hardly at all handsomer than you, I assure you; for I think
you both excessively pretty, and so does Mr. Palmer too I am sure,
though we could not get him to own it last night.
subQuotationList:
['Oh! yes, extremely well; that is, I do not believe many people are
acquainted with him, because Combe Magna is so far off; but they all
think him extremely agreeable I assure you. Nobody is more liked than
Mr. Willoughby wherever he goes, and so you may tell your sister. She
is a monstrous lucky girl to get him, upon my honour; not but that he
is much more lucky in getting her, because she is so very handsome and
agreeable, that nothing can be good enough for her. However, I don t
think her hardly at all handsomer than you, I assure you; for I think
you both excessively pretty, and so does Mr. Palmer too I am sure,
though we could not get him to own it last night.']
speaker: Charlotte
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Elinor'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Elinor'], ['Marianne'], ['Marianne'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Mr. Willoughby'], ['Marianne'], ['Marianne'], ['Marianne'], ['Marianne'], ['Elinor'], ['Elinor'], ['Marianne', 'Elinor'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Palmer'], ['Charlotte', 'Mr. Palmer'], ['Mr. Palmer']]]

quoteText:
I am so glad we are got acquainted at last, And
now I hope we shall always be great friends. You can t think how much I
longed to see you! It is so delightful that you should live at the
cottage! Nothing can be like it, to be sure! And I am so glad your
sister is going to be well married! I hope you will be a great deal at
Combe Magna. It is a sweet place, by all accounts.
subQuotationList:
['I am so glad we are got acquainted at last,', 'And
now I hope we shall always be great friends. You can t think how much I
longed to see you! It is so delightful that you should live at the
cottage! Nothing can be like it, to be sure! And I am so glad your
sister is going to be well married! I hope you will be a great deal at
Combe Magna. It is a sweet place, by all accounts.']
speaker: Charlotte

quoteText: You have been long acquainted with Colonel Brandon, have not you?
subQuotationList: ['You have been long acquainted with Colonel Brandon, have not you?']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Yes, a great while; ever since my sister married. He was a particular
friend of Sir John s. I believe, he would
have been very glad to have had me, if he could. Sir John and Lady
Middleton wished it very much. But mama did not think the match good
enough for me, otherwise Sir John would have mentioned it to the
Colonel, and we should have been married immediately.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, a great while; ever since my sister married. He was a particular
friend of Sir John s. I believe,', 'he would
have been very glad to have had me, if he could. Sir John and Lady
Middleton wished it very much. But mama did not think the match good
enough for me, otherwise Sir John would have mentioned it to the
Colonel, and we should have been married immediately.']
speaker: Charlotte
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Colonel Brandon'], ['John Middleton'], ['John Middleton']], [['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['John Middleton'], ['John Middleton'], ['Lady Middleton'], ['John Middleton'], ['John Middleton'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Charlotte', 'Colonel Brandon']]]

quoteText:
Did not Colonel Brandon know of Sir John s proposal to your mother
before it was made? Had he never owned his affection to yourself?
subQuotationList: ['Did not Colonel Brandon know of Sir John s proposal to your mother\nbefore it was made? Had he never owned his affection to yourself?']
speaker: Elinor
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['John Middleton'], ['John Middleton'], ['Mrs. Jennings'], ['Colonel Brandon'], ['Colonel Brandon']]]

quoteText:
Oh, no; but if mama had not objected to it, I dare say he would have
liked it of all things. He had not seen me then above twice, for it was
before I left school. However, I am much happier as I am. Mr. Palmer is
the kind of man I like.
subQuotationList:
['Oh, no; but if mama had not objected to it, I dare say he would have
liked it of all things. He had not seen me then above twice, for it was
before I left school. However, I am much happier as I am. Mr. Palmer is
the kind of man I like.']
speaker: Charlotte

quoteText:
Do come now, pray come you must come I declare you shall
come You can t think how you will like them. Lucy is monstrous pretty,
and so good humoured and agreeable! The children are all hanging about
her already, as if she was an old acquaintance. And they both long to
see you of all things, for they have heard at Exeter that you are the
most beautiful creatures in the world; and I have told them it is all
very true, and a great deal more. You will be delighted with them I am
sure. They have brought the whole coach full of playthings for the
children. How can you be so cross as not to come? Why they are your
cousins, you know, after a fashion. _You_ are my cousins, and they are
my wife s, so you must be related.
subQuotationList:
['Do come now,', 'pray come you must come I declare you shall
come You can t think how you will like them. Lucy is monstrous pretty,
and so good humoured and agreeable! The children are all hanging about
her already, as if she was an old acquaintance. And they both long to
see you of all things, for they have heard at Exeter that you are the
most beautiful creatures in the world; and I have told them it is all
very true, and a great deal more. You will be delighted with them I am
sure. They have brought the whole coach full of playthings for the
children. How can you be so cross as not to come? Why they are your
cousins, you know, after a fashion. _You_ are my cousins, and they are
my wife s, so you must be related.']
speaker: John Middleton
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Marianne', 'Elinor', 'Margaret'], ['Marianne', 'Elinor', 'Margaret'], ['Marianne', 'Elinor', 'Margaret'], ['Marianne', 'Elinor', 'Margaret'], ['Lucy Steele', 'Anne Steele'], ['Lucy Steele'], ['Lucy Steele'], ['Lucy Steele'], ['Lucy Steele', 'Anne Steele'], ['Marianne', 'Elinor', 'Margaret'], ['Lucy Steele', 'Anne Steele'], ['Marianne', 'Elinor', 'Margaret'], ['Lucy Steele', 'Anne Steele'], ['Marianne', 'Elinor', 'Margaret'], ['Lucy Steele', 'Anne Steele'], ['Lucy Steele', 'Anne Steele'], ['Marianne', 'Elinor', 'Margaret'], ['Lucy Steele', 'Anne Steele'], ['Anne Steele', 'Lucy Steele'], ['Elinor', 'Margaret', 'Marianne'], ['Marianne', 'Elinor', 'Margaret'], ['Elinor', 'Margaret', 'Marianne'], ['Lucy Steele', 'Anne Steele'], ['Anne Steele', 'Lucy Steele'], ['Marianne', 'Elinor', 'Margaret']]]

quoteText:
John is in such spirits today! He is full of
monkey tricks.
subQuotationList: ['John is in such spirits today!', 'He is full of\nmonkey tricks.']
speaker: Lady Middleton

quoteText: How playful William is!
subQuotationList: ['How playful William is!']
speaker: Lady Middleton

quoteText:
And here is my sweet little Annamaria, And she is always so gentle and quiet Never was there
such a quiet little thing!
subQuotationList: ['And here is my sweet little Annamaria,', 'And she is always so gentle and quiet Never was there\nsuch a quiet little thing!']
speaker: Lady Middleton

quoteText: Poor little creatures! It might have been a very sad accident.
subQuotationList: ['Poor little creatures!', 'It might have been a very sad accident.']
speaker: Anne Steele

quoteText:
Yet I hardly know how, unless it had been under
totally different circumstances. But this is the usual way of
heightening alarm, where there is nothing to be alarmed at in reality.
subQuotationList: ['Yet I hardly know how,', 'unless it had been under\ntotally different circumstances. But this is the usual way of\nheightening alarm, where there is nothing to be alarmed at in reality.']
speaker: Marianne

quoteText: What a sweet woman Lady Middleton is!
subQuotationList: ['What a sweet woman Lady Middleton is!']
speaker: Lucy Steele

quoteText:
And Sir John too, what a charming man he
is!
subQuotationList: ['And Sir John too,', 'what a charming man he\nis!']
speaker: Anne Steele

quoteText:
And what a charming little family they have! I never saw such fine
children in my life. I declare I quite doat upon them already, and
indeed I am always distractedly fond of children.
subQuotationList: ['And what a charming little family they have! I never saw such fine\nchildren in my life. I declare I quite doat upon them already, and\nindeed I am always distractedly fond of children.']
speaker: Anne Steele

quoteText:
I should guess so, from what I have
witnessed this morning.
subQuotationList: ['I should guess so,', 'from what I have\nwitnessed this morning.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
I have a notion, you think the little Middletons rather
too much indulged; perhaps they may be the outside of enough; but it is
so natural in Lady Middleton; and for my part, I love to see children
full of life and spirits; I cannot bear them if they are tame and
quiet.
subQuotationList:
['I have a notion,', 'you think the little Middletons rather
too much indulged; perhaps they may be the outside of enough; but it is
so natural in Lady Middleton; and for my part, I love to see children
full of life and spirits; I cannot bear them if they are tame and
quiet.']
speaker: Lucy Steele

quoteText:
I confess, that while I am at Barton Park, I never
think of tame and quiet children with any abhorrence.
subQuotationList: ['I confess,', 'that while I am at Barton Park, I never\nthink of tame and quiet children with any abhorrence.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
And how do you like Devonshire, Miss Dashwood? I
suppose you were very sorry to leave Sussex.
subQuotationList: ['And how do you like Devonshire, Miss Dashwood? I\nsuppose you were very sorry to leave Sussex.']
speaker: Anne Steele
referringExpression: Miss Steele who seemed very much disposed for conversation and who now said

quoteText: Norland is a prodigious beautiful place, is not it?
subQuotationList: ['Norland is a prodigious beautiful place, is not it?']
speaker: Anne Steele

quoteText: We have heard Sir John admire it excessively,
subQuotationList: ['We have heard Sir John admire it excessively,']
speaker: Lucy Steele

quoteText:
I think every one _must_ admire it, who ever saw the
place; though it is not to be supposed that any one can estimate its
beauties as we do.
subQuotationList: ['I think every one _must_ admire it,', 'who ever saw the\nplace; though it is not to be supposed that any one can estimate its\nbeauties as we do.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
And had you a great many smart beaux there? I suppose you have not so
many in this part of the world; for my part, I think they are a vast
addition always.
subQuotationList: ['And had you a great many smart beaux there? I suppose you have not so\nmany in this part of the world; for my part, I think they are a vast\naddition always.']
speaker: Anne Steele

quoteText: But why should you think, that there are not as many genteel young men in Devonshire as Sussex?
subQuotationList: ['But why should you think,', 'that there are not as many genteel young men in Devonshire as Sussex?']
speaker: Lucy Steele

quoteText:
Nay, my dear, I m sure I don t pretend to say that there an t. I m
sure there s a vast many smart beaux in Exeter; but you know, how could
I tell what smart beaux there might be about Norland; and I was only
afraid the Miss Dashwoods might find it dull at Barton, if they had not
so many as they used to have. But perhaps you young ladies may not care
about the beaux, and had as lief be without them as with them. For my
part, I think they are vastly agreeable, provided they dress smart and
behave civil. But I can t bear to see them dirty and nasty. Now there s
Mr. Rose at Exeter, a prodigious smart young man, quite a beau, clerk
to Mr. Simpson, you know, and yet if you do but meet him of a morning,
he is not fit to be seen. I suppose your brother was quite a beau, Miss
Dashwood, before he married, as he was so rich?
subQuotationList:
['Nay, my dear, I m sure I don t pretend to say that there an t. I m
sure there s a vast many smart beaux in Exeter; but you know, how could
I tell what smart beaux there might be about Norland; and I was only
afraid the Miss Dashwoods might find it dull at Barton, if they had not
so many as they used to have. But perhaps you young ladies may not care
about the beaux, and had as lief be without them as with them. For my
part, I think they are vastly agreeable, provided they dress smart and
behave civil. But I can t bear to see them dirty and nasty. Now there s
Mr. Rose at Exeter, a prodigious smart young man, quite a beau, clerk
to Mr. Simpson, you know, and yet if you do but meet him of a morning,
he is not fit to be seen. I suppose your brother was quite a beau, Miss
Dashwood, before he married, as he was so rich?']
speaker: Anne Steele

quoteText:
Upon my word, I cannot tell you, for I do not
perfectly comprehend the meaning of the word. But this I can say, that
if he ever was a beau before he married, he is one still for there is
not the smallest alteration in him.
subQuotationList:
['Upon my word,', 'I cannot tell you, for I do not
perfectly comprehend the meaning of the word. But this I can say, that
if he ever was a beau before he married, he is one still for there is
not the smallest alteration in him.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Oh! dear! one never thinks of married men s being beaux they have
something else to do.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! dear! one never thinks of married men s being beaux they have\nsomething else to do.']
speaker: Anne Steele

quoteText:
Lord! Anne, you can talk of nothing but beaux; you
will make Miss Dashwood believe you think of nothing else.
subQuotationList: ['Lord! Anne,', 'you can talk of nothing but beaux; you\nwill make Miss Dashwood believe you think of nothing else.']
speaker: Lucy Steele

quoteText:
Twill be a fine thing to have her married so young to be sure, and I hear he is quite a beau, and prodigious handsome. And I
hope you may have as good luck yourself soon, but perhaps you may have
a friend in the corner already.
subQuotationList: ['Twill be a fine thing to have her married so young to be sure,', 'and I hear he is quite a beau, and prodigious handsome. And I\nhope you may have as good luck yourself soon, but perhaps you may have\na friend in the corner already.']
speaker: Anne Steele

quoteText:
His name is Ferrars, but pray do
not tell it, for it s a great secret.
subQuotationList: ['His name is Ferrars,', 'but pray do\nnot tell it, for it s a great secret.']
speaker: John Middleton

quoteText:
Ferrars! Mr. Ferrars is the happy man, is he?
What! your sister-in-law s brother, Miss Dashwood? a very agreeable
young man to be sure; I know him very well.
subQuotationList: ['Ferrars!', 'Mr. Ferrars is the happy man, is he?\nWhat! your sister-in-law s brother, Miss Dashwood? a very agreeable\nyoung man to be sure; I know him very well.']
speaker: Anne Steele
mentionTextsList: [['Ferrars'], ['Mr. Ferrars', 'Ferrars', 'he', 'your sister-in-law s brother', 'Miss Dashwood', 'Dashwood', 'a very agreeable\nyoung man', 'him']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Edward Ferrars']], [['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Elinor'], ['Elinor'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars']]]

quoteText:
How can you say so, Anne? Though we have seen him once or twice
at my uncle s, it is rather too much to pretend to know him very well.
subQuotationList: ['How can you say so, Anne?', 'Though we have seen him once or twice\nat my uncle s, it is rather too much to pretend to know him very well.']
speaker: Lucy Steele
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Anne Steele'], ['Anne Steele']], [['Lucy Steele', 'Anne Steele'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars']]]

quoteText:
And who was this
uncle? Where did he live? How came they acquainted?
subQuotationList: ['And who was this\nuncle? Where did he live? How came they acquainted?']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
You will think my question an odd one, I dare say, but pray, are you personally acquainted with your
sister-in-law s mother, Mrs. Ferrars?
subQuotationList: ['You will think my question an odd one, I dare say,', 'but pray, are you personally acquainted with your\nsister-in-law s mother, Mrs. Ferrars?']
speaker: Lucy Steele

quoteText:
Indeed! I wonder at that, for I thought you must have
seen her at Norland sometimes. Then, perhaps, you cannot tell me what
sort of a woman she is?
subQuotationList: ['Indeed!', 'I wonder at that, for I thought you must have\nseen her at Norland sometimes. Then, perhaps, you cannot tell me what\nsort of a woman she is?']
speaker: Lucy Steele

quoteText: No, I know nothing of her.
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'I know nothing of her.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
I am sure you think me very strange, for enquiring about her in such a
way, but perhaps
there may be reasons I wish I might venture; but however I hope you
will do me the justice of believing that I do not mean to be
impertinent.
subQuotationList:
['I am sure you think me very strange, for enquiring about her in such a
way,', 'but perhaps
there may be reasons I wish I might venture; but however I hope you
will do me the justice of believing that I do not mean to be
impertinent.']
speaker: Lucy Steele

quoteText:
I cannot bear to have you think me impertinently curious. I am sure I
would rather do any thing in the world than be thought so by a person
whose good opinion is so well worth having as yours. And I am sure I
should not have the smallest fear of trusting _you;_ indeed, I should
be very glad of your advice how to manage in such an uncomfortable
situation as I am; but, however, there is no occasion to trouble _you_.
I am sorry you do not happen to know Mrs. Ferrars.
subQuotationList:
['I cannot bear to have you think me impertinently curious. I am sure I
would rather do any thing in the world than be thought so by a person
whose good opinion is so well worth having as yours. And I am sure I
should not have the smallest fear of trusting _you;_ indeed, I should
be very glad of your advice how to manage in such an uncomfortable
situation as I am; but, however, there is no occasion to trouble _you_.
I am sorry you do not happen to know Mrs. Ferrars.']
speaker: Lucy Steele
referringExpression: Lucy who renewed the subject again by saying

quoteText:
I am sorry I do _not_, if it
could be of any use to YOU to know my opinion of her. But really I
never understood that you were at all connected with that family, and
therefore I am a little surprised, I confess, at so serious an inquiry
into her character.
subQuotationList:
['I am sorry I do _not_,', 'if it
could be of any use to YOU to know my opinion of her. But really I
never understood that you were at all connected with that family, and
therefore I am a little surprised, I confess, at so serious an inquiry
into her character.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
I dare say you are, and I am sure I do not at all wonder at it. But if
I dared tell you all, you would not be so much surprised. Mrs. Ferrars
is certainly nothing to me at present but the time _may_ come how soon
it will come must depend upon herself when we may be very intimately
connected.
subQuotationList:
['I dare say you are, and I am sure I do not at all wonder at it. But if
I dared tell you all, you would not be so much surprised. Mrs. Ferrars
is certainly nothing to me at present but the time _may_ come how soon
it will come must depend upon herself when we may be very intimately
connected.']
speaker: Lucy Steele

quoteText:
Good heavens! what do you mean? Are you acquainted
with Mr. Robert Ferrars? Can you be?
subQuotationList: ['Good heavens!', 'what do you mean? Are you acquainted\nwith Mr. Robert Ferrars? Can you be?']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
No, not to Mr. _Robert_ Ferrars I never saw him in my
life; but, to his eldest brother.
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'not to Mr. _Robert_ Ferrars I never saw him in my\nlife; but,', 'to his eldest brother.']
speaker: Lucy Steele

quoteText:
You may well be surprised, for to be sure you could
have had no idea of it before; for I dare say he never dropped the
smallest hint of it to you or any of your family; because it was always
meant to be a great secret, and I am sure has been faithfully kept so
by me to this hour. Not a soul of all my relations know of it but Anne,
and I never should have mentioned it to you, if I had not felt the
greatest dependence in the world upon your secrecy; and I really
thought my behaviour in asking so many questions about Mrs. Ferrars
must seem so odd, that it ought to be explained. And I do not think Mr.
Ferrars can be displeased, when he knows I have trusted you, because I
know he has the highest opinion in the world of all your family, and
looks upon yourself and the other Miss Dashwoods quite as his own
sisters.
subQuotationList:
['You may well be surprised,', 'for to be sure you could
have had no idea of it before; for I dare say he never dropped the
smallest hint of it to you or any of your family; because it was always
meant to be a great secret, and I am sure has been faithfully kept so
by me to this hour. Not a soul of all my relations know of it but Anne,
and I never should have mentioned it to you, if I had not felt the
greatest dependence in the world upon your secrecy; and I really
thought my behaviour in asking so many questions about Mrs. Ferrars
must seem so odd, that it ought to be explained. And I do not think Mr.
Ferrars can be displeased, when he knows I have trusted you, because I
know he has the highest opinion in the world of all your family, and
looks upon yourself and the other Miss Dashwoods quite as his own
sisters.']
speaker: Lucy Steele
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elinor']], [['Elinor'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Elinor'], ['Anne Steele'], ['Elinor'], ['Mrs. Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Elinor'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Mrs. Dashwood', 'Marianne', 'Elinor', 'Margaret'], ['Marianne', 'Margaret']]]

quoteText:
May I ask
if your engagement is of long standing?
subQuotationList: ['May I ask\nif your engagement is of long standing?']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText: We have been engaged these four years.
subQuotationList: ['We have been engaged these four years.']
speaker: Lucy Steele

quoteText: Four years!
subQuotationList: ['Four years!']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Lucy Steele

quoteText:
I did not know, that you were even acquainted till the
other day.
subQuotationList: ['I did not know,', 'that you were even acquainted till the\nother day.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Our acquaintance, however, is of many years date. He was under my
uncle s care, you know, a considerable while.
subQuotationList: ['Our acquaintance, however, is of many years date. He was under my\nuncle s care, you know, a considerable while.']
speaker: Lucy Steele

quoteText: Your uncle!
subQuotationList: ['Your uncle!']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText: Yes; Mr. Pratt. Did you never hear him talk of Mr. Pratt?
subQuotationList: ['Yes; Mr. Pratt. Did you never hear him talk of Mr. Pratt?']
speaker: Lucy Steele

quoteText: I think I have,
subQuotationList: ['I think I have,']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
He was four years with my uncle, who lives at Longstaple, near
Plymouth. It was there our acquaintance begun, for my sister and me was
often staying with my uncle, and it was there our engagement was
formed, though not till a year after he had quitted as a pupil; but he
was almost always with us afterwards. I was very unwilling to enter
into it, as you may imagine, without the knowledge and approbation of
his mother; but I was too young, and loved him too well, to be so
prudent as I ought to have been. Though you do not know him so well as
me, Miss Dashwood, you must have seen enough of him to be sensible he
is very capable of making a woman sincerely attached to him.
subQuotationList:
['He was four years with my uncle, who lives at Longstaple, near
Plymouth. It was there our acquaintance begun, for my sister and me was
often staying with my uncle, and it was there our engagement was
formed, though not till a year after he had quitted as a pupil; but he
was almost always with us afterwards. I was very unwilling to enter
into it, as you may imagine, without the knowledge and approbation of
his mother; but I was too young, and loved him too well, to be so
prudent as I ought to have been. Though you do not know him so well as
me, Miss Dashwood, you must have seen enough of him to be sensible he
is very capable of making a woman sincerely attached to him.']
speaker: Lucy Steele
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Edward Ferrars'], ['Anne Steele'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Lucy Steele', 'Anne Steele'], ['Elinor'], ['Mrs. Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Elinor'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Elinor'], ['Elinor'], ['Elinor'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars']]]

quoteText:
Certainly, Engaged to Mr. Edward
Ferrars! I confess myself so totally surprised at what you tell me,
that really I beg your pardon; but surely there must be some mistake of
person or name. We cannot mean the same Mr. Ferrars.
subQuotationList:
['Certainly,', 'Engaged to Mr. Edward
Ferrars! I confess myself so totally surprised at what you tell me,
that really I beg your pardon; but surely there must be some mistake of
person or name. We cannot mean the same Mr. Ferrars.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
We can mean no other, Mr. Edward Ferrars, the
eldest son of Mrs. Ferrars, of Park Street, and brother of your
sister-in-law, Mrs. John Dashwood, is the person I mean; you must allow
that I am not likely to be deceived as to the name of the man on who
all my happiness depends.
subQuotationList:
['We can mean no other,', 'Mr. Edward Ferrars, the
eldest son of Mrs. Ferrars, of Park Street, and brother of your
sister-in-law, Mrs. John Dashwood, is the person I mean; you must allow
that I am not likely to be deceived as to the name of the man on who
all my happiness depends.']
speaker: Lucy Steele

[['We'], ['Mr. Edward Ferrars', 'Edward', 'Ferrars', 'the
eldest son of Mrs. Ferrars', 'Mrs.', 'Ferrars', 'brother of your
sister-in-law', 'your
sister-in-law, Mrs. ', 'Mrs. John Dashwood', 'John', 'Dashwood', 'you']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elinor', 'Lucy Steele']], [['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Mrs. Ferrars'], ['Mrs. Ferrars'], ['Edward Ferrars'], ['Fanny'], ['Fanny'], ['Fanny'], ['Fanny'], ['Elinor']]]

quoteText:
It is strange, that I
should never have heard him even mention your name.
subQuotationList: ['It is strange,', 'that I\nshould never have heard him even mention your name.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
No; considering our situation, it was not strange. Our first care has
been to keep the matter secret. You knew nothing of me, or my family,
and, therefore, there could be no _occasion_ for ever mentioning my
name to you; and, as he was always particularly afraid of his sister s
suspecting any thing, _that_ was reason enough for his not mentioning
it.
subQuotationList:
['No; considering our situation, it was not strange. Our first care has
been to keep the matter secret. You knew nothing of me, or my family,
and, therefore, there could be no _occasion_ for ever mentioning my
name to you; and, as he was always particularly afraid of his sister s
suspecting any thing, _that_ was reason enough for his not mentioning
it.']
speaker: Lucy Steele

quoteText: Four years you have been engaged,
subQuotationList: ['Four years you have been engaged,']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
Yes; and heaven knows how much longer we may have to wait. Poor
Edward! It puts him quite out of heart.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; and heaven knows how much longer we may have to wait. Poor\nEdward! It puts him quite out of heart.']
speaker: Lucy Steele

quoteText:
To prevent the possibility of mistake, be
so good as to look at this face. It does not do him justice, to be
sure, but yet I think you cannot be deceived as to the person it was
drew for. I have had it above these three years.
subQuotationList:
['To prevent the possibility of mistake, be
so good as to look at this face. It does not do him justice, to be
sure, but yet I think you cannot be deceived as to the person it was
drew for. I have had it above these three years.']
speaker: Lucy Steele

quoteText:
I have never been able, to give him my picture in
return, which I am very much vexed at, for he has been always so
anxious to get it! But I am determined to set for it the very first
opportunity.
subQuotationList:
['I have never been able,', 'to give him my picture in
return, which I am very much vexed at, for he has been always so
anxious to get it! But I am determined to set for it the very first
opportunity.']
speaker: Lucy Steele

quoteText: You are quite in the right,
subQuotationList: ['You are quite in the right,']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
I am sure, I have no doubt in the world of your faithfully
keeping this secret, because you must know of what importance it is to
us, not to have it reach his mother; for she would never approve of it,
I dare say. I shall have no fortune, and I fancy she is an exceeding
proud woman.
subQuotationList:
['I am sure,', 'I have no doubt in the world of your faithfully
keeping this secret, because you must know of what importance it is to
us, not to have it reach his mother; for she would never approve of it,
I dare say. I shall have no fortune, and I fancy she is an exceeding
proud woman.']
speaker: Lucy Steele

quoteText:
I certainly did not seek your confidence, but you do me
no more than justice in imagining that I may be depended on. Your
secret is safe with me; but pardon me if I express some surprise at so
unnecessary a communication. You must at least have felt that my being
acquainted with it could not add to its safety.
subQuotationList:
['I certainly did not seek your confidence,', 'but you do me
no more than justice in imagining that I may be depended on. Your
secret is safe with me; but pardon me if I express some surprise at so
unnecessary a communication. You must at least have felt that my being
acquainted with it could not add to its safety.']
speaker: Elinor

quoteText:
I was afraid you would think I was taking a great liberty with you, in telling you all this. I have not known you long to be
sure, personally at least, but I have known you and all your family by
description a great while; and as soon as I saw you, I felt almost as
if you was an old acquaintance. Besides in the present case, I really
thought some explanation was due to you after my making such particular
inquiries about Edward s mother; and I am so unfortunate, that I have
not a creature whose advice I can ask. Anne is the only person that
knows of it, and she has no judgment at all; indeed, she does me a
great deal more harm than good, for I am in constant fear of her
betraying me. She does not know how to hold her tongue, as you must
perceive, and I am sure I was in the greatest fright in the world
t other day, when Edward s name was mentioned by Sir John, lest she
should out with it all. You can t think how much I go through in my
mind from it altogether. I only wonder that I am alive after what I
have suffered for Edward s sake these last four years. Every thing in
such suspense and uncertainty; and seeing him so seldom we can hardly
meet above twice a-year. I am sure I wonder my heart is not quite
broke.
subQuotationList:
['I was afraid you would think I was taking a great liberty with you,', 'in telling you all this. I have not known you long to be
sure, personally at least, but I have known you and all your family by
description a great while; and as soon as I saw you, I felt almost as
